House File 2167 - Introduced


                                 HOUSE FILE 

                                 HOUSE FILE 
                                 HOUSE FILE                                  HOUSE FILE                                  BY  ANDERSON, DAWSON,
                                     McCONKEY, MASCHER,
                                     STAED, HANSON, THEDE,
                                     HUNTER, FINKENAUER,
                                     STUTSMAN, LENSING, and
                                     BENNETT

 A BILL FOR

  1 An Act relating to civil protective orders and dating abuse,
  2    creating the criminal offense of dating abuse assault,
  3    making related modifications, and providing penalties.
  4 BE IT ENACTED BY THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY OF THE STATE OF IOWA:
    TLSB 5256HH (9) 86
    rh/rj

PAG LIN

  1  2 follows:

  1  4    The general assembly finds that individuals attempting to
  1  5 escape from actual or threatened domestic abuse, domestic
  1  6 abuse assault,                                      McCONKEY, MASCHER,

  4 33    Sec. 14.    4 33    Sec. 14.    4 34    This chapter may be cited as the "Dating Abuse Act".
  4 35    Sec. 15.    4 35    Sec. 15.    5  1 For purposes of this chapter, unless a different meaning is
  5  2 clearly indicated by the context:
  5  3    1.  "Dating abuse" means committing assault as defined in
  5  4 section 708.1 under any of the following circumstances:
  5  5    a.  The assault is between persons who are in a dating
  5  6 relationship or have been in a dating relationship and have had
  5  7 contact within the past year of the assault. In determining
  5  8 whether persons are or have been in a dating relationship, the
  5  9 court may consider the following nonexclusive list of factors:
  5 10    (1)  The duration of the dating relationship.
  5 11    (2)  The frequency of interaction.
  5 12    (3)  Whether the dating relationship has been terminated.
  5 13    (4)  The nature of the dating relationship, characterized by
  5 14 either party's expectation of sexual, romantic, or affectional
  5 15 involvement.
  5 16    b.  A person may be involved in a dating relationship with
  5 17 more than one person at a time.
  5 18    2.  "Dating relationship" means a significant romantic
  5 19 or affectional relationship that need not include sexual
  5 20 involvement.  A dating relationship does not include casual
  5 21 social relationships or associations in a business or
  5 22 professional capacity.
  5 23    3.  "Department" means the department of justice.
  5 24    4.  "Emergency shelter services" include but are not limited
  5 25 to secure crisis shelters or housing for victims of dating
  5 26 abuse.
  5 27    5.  "Plaintiff" includes a person filing an action on behalf
  5 28 of an unemancipated minor.
  5 29    6.  "Pro se" means a person proceeding on the person's own
  5 30 behalf without legal representation.
  5 31    7.  "Support services" include but are not limited to legal
  5 32 services, counseling services, transportation services, child
  5 33 care services, and advocacy services.
  5 34    Sec. 16.    5  2 clearly indicated by the context:
  5  3    1.  "Dating abuse" means committing assault as defined in
  5  4 section 708.1 under any of the following circumstances:
  5  5    a.  The assault is between persons who are in a dating
  5  6 relationship or have been in a dating relationship and have had

  5 15 involvement.

  5 17 more than one person at a time.

  5 21 social relationships or associations in a business or

  5 30 behalf without legal representation.
  5 31    7.  "Support services" include but are not limited to legal
  5 32 services, counseling services, transportation services, child
  5 33 care services, and advocacy services.

  5 34    Sec. 16.    5 20 involvement.  A dating relationship does not include casual
  5 21 social relationships or associations in a business or
  5 22 professional capacity.
  5 23    3.  "Department" means the department of justice.
  5 24    4.  "Emergency shelter services" include but are not limited
  5 25 to secure crisis shelters or housing for victims of dating
  5 26 abuse.
  5 27    5.  "Plaintiff" includes a person filing an action on behalf
  5 28 of an unemancipated minor.
  5 29    6.  "Pro se" means a person proceeding on the person's own
  5 30 behalf without legal representation.
  5 31    7.  "Support services" include but are not limited to legal
  5 32 services, counseling services, transportation services, child
  5 33 care services, and advocacy services.
  5 34    Sec. 16.    5 21 social relationships or associations in a business or
  5 22 professional capacity.
  5 23    3.  "Department" means the department of justice.
  5 24    4.  "Emergency shelter services" include but are not limited
  5 25 to secure crisis shelters or housing for victims of dating
  5 26 abuse.

  5 28 of an unemancipated minor.

  5 30 behalf without legal representation.
  5 31    7.  "Support services" include but are not limited to legal
  5 32 services, counseling services, transportation services, child
  5 33 care services, and advocacy services.

  5 33 care services, and advocacy services.
  5 34    Sec. 16.    5 33 care services, and advocacy services.
  5 34    Sec. 16.    5 34    Sec. 16.    5 35 waiver to juvenile court.
  6  1    1.  A person, including a parent or guardian on behalf of
  6  2 an unemancipated minor, may seek relief from dating abuse by
  6  3 filing a verified petition in the district court. Venue shall
  6  4 lie where either party resides. The petition shall state the
  6  5 following:
  6  6    a.  Name of the plaintiff and the name and address of the
  6  7 plaintiff's attorney, if any. If the plaintiff is proceeding
  6  8 pro se, the petition shall state a mailing address for the
  6  9 plaintiff. A mailing address may be provided by the plaintiff
  6 10 pursuant to section 236A.11.
  6 11    b.  Name and address of the parent or guardian filing the
  6 12 petition, if the petition is being filed on behalf of an
  6 13 unemancipated minor. A mailing address may be provided by the
  6 14 plaintiff pursuant to section 236A.11.
  6 15    c.  Name and address, if known, of the defendant.
  6 16    d.  Nature of the alleged dating abuse.
  6 17    e.  Name and age of each child under eighteen whose welfare
  6 18 may be affected by the controversy.
  6 19    f.  Desired relief, including a request for temporary or
  6 20 emergency orders.
  6 21    2.  A temporary or emergency order shall be based on a
  6 22 showing of a prima facie case of dating abuse. If the factual
  6 23 basis for the alleged dating abuse is contested, the court
  6 24 shall issue a protective order based upon a finding of dating
  6 25 abuse by a preponderance of the evidence.
  6 26    3.  a.  The filing fee and court costs for an order for
  6 27 protection and in a contempt action under this chapter shall be
  6 28 waived for the plaintiff.
  6 29    b.  The clerk of court, the sheriff of any county in this
  6 30 state, and other law enforcement and corrections officers shall
  6 31 perform their duties relating to service of process without
  6 32 charge to the plaintiff. When an order for protection is
  6 33 entered by the court, the court may direct the defendant to pay
  6 34 to the clerk of court the fees for the filing of the petition
  6 35 and reasonable costs of service of process if the court
  7  1 determines the defendant has the ability to pay the plaintiff's
  7  2 fees and costs. In lieu of personal service of an order for
  7  3 protection issued pursuant to this section, the sheriff of any
  7  4 county in this state and other law enforcement and corrections
  7  5 officers may serve a defendant with a short=form notification
  7  6 pursuant to section 664A.4A.
  7  7    4.  If the person against whom relief from dating abuse is
  7  8 being sought is seventeen years of age or younger, the district
  7  9 court shall waive its jurisdiction over the action to the
  7 10 juvenile court.
  7 11    Sec. 17.    6  1    1.  A person, including a parent or guardian on behalf of
  6  2 an unemancipated minor, may seek relief from dating abuse by
  6  3 filing a verified petition in the district court. Venue shall

  6  5 following:

  6 18 may be affected by the controversy.

  6 20 emergency orders.

  6 16    d.  Nature of the alleged dating abuse.
  6 17    e.  Name and age of each child under eighteen whose welfare
  6 18 may be affected by the controversy.
  6 19    f.  Desired relief, including a request for temporary or
  6 20 emergency orders.
  6 21    2.  A temporary or emergency order shall be based on a
  6 22 showing of a prima facie case of dating abuse. If the factual
  6 23 basis for the alleged dating abuse is contested, the court
  6 24 shall issue a protective order based upon a finding of dating
  6 25 abuse by a preponderance of the evidence.
  6 26    3.  a.  The filing fee and court costs for an order for
  6 27 protection and in a contempt action under this chapter shall be
  6 28 waived for the plaintiff.
  6 29    b.  The clerk of court, the sheriff of any county in this
  6 30 state, and other law enforcement and corrections officers shall
  6 31 perform their duties relating to service of process without
  6 32 charge to the plaintiff. When an order for protection is
  6 33 entered by the court, the court may direct the defendant to pay
  6 34 to the clerk of court the fees for the filing of the petition
  6 35 and reasonable costs of service of process if the court
  7  1 determines the defendant has the ability to pay the plaintiff's
  7  2 fees and costs. In lieu of personal service of an order for
  7  3 protection issued pursuant to this section, the sheriff of any
  7  4 county in this state and other law enforcement and corrections
  7  5 officers may serve a defendant with a short=form notification
  7  6 pursuant to section 664A.4A.
  7  7    4.  If the person against whom relief from dating abuse is
  7  8 being sought is seventeen years of age or younger, the district
  7  9 court shall waive its jurisdiction over the action to the
  7 10 juvenile court.
  7 11    Sec. 17.    6 10 pursuant to section 236A.11.
  6 11    b.  Name and address of the parent or guardian filing the
  6 12 petition, if the petition is being filed on behalf of an
  6 13 unemancipated minor. A mailing address may be provided by the
  6 14 plaintiff pursuant to section 236A.11.
  6 15    c.  Name and address, if known, of the defendant.
  6 16    d.  Nature of the alleged dating abuse.
  6 17    e.  Name and age of each child under eighteen whose welfare
  6 18 may be affected by the controversy.
  6 19    f.  Desired relief, including a request for temporary or
  6 20 emergency orders.

  6 22 showing of a prima facie case of dating abuse. If the factual
  6 23 basis for the alleged dating abuse is contested, the court
  6 24 shall issue a protective order based upon a finding of dating
  6 25 abuse by a preponderance of the evidence.

  6 32 charge to the plaintiff. When an order for protection is
  6 33 entered by the court, the court may direct the defendant to pay
  6 34 to the clerk of court the fees for the filing of the petition
  6 35 and reasonable costs of service of process if the court
  7  1 determines the defendant has the ability to pay the plaintiff's
  7  2 fees and costs. In lieu of personal service of an order for
  7  3 protection issued pursuant to this section, the sheriff of any
  7  4 county in this state and other law enforcement and corrections
  7  5 officers may serve a defendant with a short=form notification
  7  6 pursuant to section 664A.4A.
  7  7    4.  If the person against whom relief from dating abuse is
  7  8 being sought is seventeen years of age or younger, the district
  7  9 court shall waive its jurisdiction over the action to the
  7 10 juvenile court.
  7 11    Sec. 17.    6 27 protection and in a contempt action under this chapter shall be
  6 28 waived for the plaintiff.
  6 29    b.  The clerk of court, the sheriff of any county in this
  6 30 state, and other law enforcement and corrections officers shall
  6 31 perform their duties relating to service of process without
  6 32 charge to the plaintiff. When an order for protection is
  6 33 entered by the court, the court may direct the defendant to pay
  6 34 to the clerk of court the fees for the filing of the petition

  7 11    Sec. 17.    7 11    Sec. 17.    7 12 ==== provision of forms and assistance.
  7 13    1.  The department shall prescribe standard forms to be
  7 14 used by plaintiffs seeking protective orders by proceeding pro
  7 15 se in actions under this chapter. The standard forms shall
  7 16 include language in fourteen point boldface type. Standard
  7 17 forms prescribed by the department shall be the exclusive forms
  7 18 used by plaintiffs proceeding pro se, and may be used by other
  7 19 plaintiffs. The department shall distribute the forms to the
  7 20 clerks of the district court.
  7 21    2.  The clerk of the district court shall furnish the
  7 22 required forms to persons seeking protective orders through pro
  7 23 se proceedings pursuant to this chapter.
  7 24    Sec. 18.    7 13    1.  The department shall prescribe standard forms to be
  7 14 used by plaintiffs seeking protective orders by proceeding pro
  7 15 se in actions under this chapter. The standard forms shall
  7 16 include language in fourteen point boldface type. Standard
  7 17 forms prescribed by the department shall be the exclusive forms
  7 18 used by plaintiffs proceeding pro se, and may be used by other
  7 19 plaintiffs. The department shall distribute the forms to the
  7 20 clerks of the district court.

  7 22 required forms to persons seeking protective orders through pro
  7 23 se proceedings pursuant to this chapter.

  7 24    Sec. 18.    7 24    Sec. 18.    7 25    A county attorney's office may provide assistance to a
  7 26 person wishing to initiate proceedings pursuant to this chapter
  7 27 or to a plaintiff at any stage of a proceeding under this
  7 28 chapter, if the individual does not have sufficient funds
  7 29 to pay for legal assistance and if the assistance does not
  7 30 create a conflict of interest for the county attorney's office.
  7 31 The assistance provided may include but is not limited to
  7 32 assistance in obtaining or completing forms, filing a petition
  7 33 or other necessary pleading, presenting evidence to the court,
  7 34 and enforcing the orders of the court entered pursuant to this
  7 35 chapter. Providing assistance pursuant to this section shall
  8  1 not be considered the private practice of law for the purposes
  8  2 of section 331.752.
  8  3    Sec. 19.    7 26 person wishing to initiate proceedings pursuant to this chapter

  8  3    Sec. 19.    8  3    Sec. 19.    8  4    1.  Not less than five and not more than fifteen days after
  8  5 commencing a proceeding and upon notice to the other party, a
  8  6 hearing shall be held at which the plaintiff must prove the
  8  7 allegation of dating abuse by a preponderance of the evidence.
  8  8    2.  The court may enter any temporary order it deems
  8  9 necessary to protect the plaintiff from dating abuse prior to
  8 10 the hearing upon good cause shown in an ex parte proceeding.
  8 11 Present danger of dating abuse to the plaintiff constitutes
  8 12 good cause for purposes of this subsection.
  8 13    3.  If a hearing is continued, the court may make or extend
  8 14 any temporary order under subsection 2 that it deems necessary.
  8 15    4.  Upon application of a party, the court shall issue
  8 16 subpoenas requiring attendance and testimony of witnesses and
  8 17 production of papers.
  8 18    5.  The court shall advise the defendant of a right to be
  8 19 represented by counsel of the defendant's choosing and to have
  8 20 a continuance to secure counsel.
  8 21    6.  Hearings shall be recorded.
  8 22    Sec. 20.    8  5 commencing a proceeding and upon notice to the other party, a
  8  6 hearing shall be held at which the plaintiff must prove the
  8  7 allegation of dating abuse by a preponderance of the evidence.
  8  8    2.  The court may enter any temporary order it deems
  8  9 necessary to protect the plaintiff from dating abuse prior to
  8 10 the hearing upon good cause shown in an ex parte proceeding.
  8 11 Present danger of dating abuse to the plaintiff constitutes
  8 12 good cause for purposes of this subsection.

  8 14 any temporary order under subsection 2 that it deems necessary.

  8 16 subpoenas requiring attendance and testimony of witnesses and

  8 22    Sec. 20.    8 12 good cause for purposes of this subsection.
  8 13    3.  If a hearing is continued, the court may make or extend
  8 14 any temporary order under subsection 2 that it deems necessary.
  8 15    4.  Upon application of a party, the court shall issue
  8 16 subpoenas requiring attendance and testimony of witnesses and
  8 17 production of papers.
  8 18    5.  The court shall advise the defendant of a right to be
  8 19 represented by counsel of the defendant's choosing and to have
  8 20 a continuance to secure counsel.
  8 21    6.  Hearings shall be recorded.
  8 22    Sec. 20.    8 13    3.  If a hearing is continued, the court may make or extend
  8 14 any temporary order under subsection 2 that it deems necessary.
  8 15    4.  Upon application of a party, the court shall issue
  8 16 subpoenas requiring attendance and testimony of witnesses and
  8 17 production of papers.
  8 18    5.  The court shall advise the defendant of a right to be
  8 19 represented by counsel of the defendant's choosing and to have
  8 20 a continuance to secure counsel.
  8 21    6.  Hearings shall be recorded.
  8 22    Sec. 20.    8 14 any temporary order under subsection 2 that it deems necessary.
  8 15    4.  Upon application of a party, the court shall issue
  8 16 subpoenas requiring attendance and testimony of witnesses and

  8 19 represented by counsel of the defendant's choosing and to have
  8 20 a continuance to secure counsel.

  8 22    Sec. 20.    8 18    5.  The court shall advise the defendant of a right to be
  8 19 represented by counsel of the defendant's choosing and to have
  8 20 a continuance to secure counsel.
  8 21    6.  Hearings shall be recorded.
  8 22    Sec. 20.    8 19 represented by counsel of the defendant's choosing and to have
  8 20 a continuance to secure counsel.
  8 21    6.  Hearings shall be recorded.
  8 22    Sec. 20.    8 20 a continuance to secure counsel.
  8 21    6.  Hearings shall be recorded.
  8 22    Sec. 20.    8 21    6.  Hearings shall be recorded.
  8 22    Sec. 20.    8 22    Sec. 20.    8 23    1.  Upon a finding that the defendant has engaged in dating
  8 24 abuse, the court may grant a protective order or approve a
  8 25 consent agreement which may contain but is not limited to any
  8 26 of the following provisions:
  8 27    a.  That the defendant cease dating abuse of the plaintiff.
  8 28    b.  That the defendant stay away from the plaintiff's
  8 29 residence, school, or place of employment.
  8 30    2.  An order for a protective order or approved consent
  8 31 agreement shall be for a fixed period of time not to exceed one
  8 32 year. The court may amend or extend its order or a consent
  8 33 agreement at any time upon a petition filed by either party
  8 34 and after notice and hearing. The court may extend the order
  8 35 if the court, after hearing at which the defendant has the
  9  1 opportunity to be heard, finds that the defendant continues to
  9  2 pose a threat to the safety of the victim, persons residing
  9  3 with the victim, or members of the victim's immediate family.
  9  4 The number of extensions that can be granted by the court is
  9  5 not limited.
  9  6    3.  The order shall state whether a person is to be taken
  9  7 into custody by a peace officer for a violation of the terms
  9  8 stated in the order.
  9  9    4.  The court may order that the defendant pay the
  9 10 plaintiff's attorney fees and court costs.
  9 11    5.  An order or consent agreement under this section shall
  9 12 not affect title to real property.
  9 13    6.  A copy of any order or approved consent agreement shall
  9 14 be issued to the plaintiff, the defendant, the county sheriff
  9 15 of the county in which the order or consent decree is initially
  9 16 entered, and the twenty=four=hour dispatcher for the county
  9 17 sheriff. A copy of any subsequent amendment or revocation of
  9 18 an order or consent agreement shall be forwarded by the clerk
  9 19 to all individuals and the county sheriff previously receiving
  9 20 a copy of the order or consent agreement.
  9 21    7.  The clerk shall notify the county sheriff and the
  9 22 twenty=four=hour dispatcher for the county sheriff in writing
  9 23 so that the county sheriff and the county sheriff's dispatcher
  9 24 receive written notice within six hours of filing the order,
  9 25 approved consent agreement, amendment, or revocation. The
  9 26 clerk may fulfill this requirement by sending the notice by
  9 27 facsimile or other electronic transmission which reproduces the
  9 28 notice in writing within six hours of filing the order.
  9 29    8.  The county sheriff's dispatcher shall notify all law
  9 30 enforcement agencies having jurisdiction over the matter
  9 31 and the twenty=four=hour dispatcher for the law enforcement
  9 32 agencies upon notification by the clerk.
  9 33    Sec. 21.    8 24 abuse, the court may grant a protective order or approve a
  8 25 consent agreement which may contain but is not limited to any
  8 26 of the following provisions:
  8 27    a.  That the defendant cease dating abuse of the plaintiff.
  8 28    b.  That the defendant stay away from the plaintiff's
  8 29 residence, school, or place of employment.
  8 30    2.  An order for a protective order or approved consent
  8 31 agreement shall be for a fixed period of time not to exceed one
  8 32 year. The court may amend or extend its order or a consent
  8 33 agreement at any time upon a petition filed by either party
  8 34 and after notice and hearing. The court may extend the order
  8 35 if the court, after hearing at which the defendant has the
  9  1 opportunity to be heard, finds that the defendant continues to
  9  2 pose a threat to the safety of the victim, persons residing
  9  3 with the victim, or members of the victim's immediate family.
  9  4 The number of extensions that can be granted by the court is
  9  5 not limited.
  9  6    3.  The order shall state whether a person is to be taken
  9  7 into custody by a peace officer for a violation of the terms
  9  8 stated in the order.
  9  9    4.  The court may order that the defendant pay the
  9 10 plaintiff's attorney fees and court costs.

  9 31 and the twenty=four=hour dispatcher for the law enforcement
  9 32 agencies upon notification by the clerk.
  9 33    Sec. 21.    8 34 and after notice and hearing. The court may extend the order
  8 35 if the court, after hearing at which the defendant has the
  9  1 opportunity to be heard, finds that the defendant continues to
  9  2 pose a threat to the safety of the victim, persons residing
  9  3 with the victim, or members of the victim's immediate family.
  9  4 The number of extensions that can be granted by the court is
  9  5 not limited.
  9  6    3.  The order shall state whether a person is to be taken
  9  7 into custody by a peace officer for a violation of the terms
  9  8 stated in the order.
  9  9    4.  The court may order that the defendant pay the
  9 10 plaintiff's attorney fees and court costs.
  9 11    5.  An order or consent agreement under this section shall
  9 12 not affect title to real property.
  9 13    6.  A copy of any order or approved consent agreement shall
  9 14 be issued to the plaintiff, the defendant, the county sheriff
  9 15 of the county in which the order or consent decree is initially
  9 16 entered, and the twenty=four=hour dispatcher for the county
  9 17 sheriff. A copy of any subsequent amendment or revocation of
  9 18 an order or consent agreement shall be forwarded by the clerk
  9 19 to all individuals and the county sheriff previously receiving
  9 20 a copy of the order or consent agreement.
  9 21    7.  The clerk shall notify the county sheriff and the
  9 22 twenty=four=hour dispatcher for the county sheriff in writing
  9 23 so that the county sheriff and the county sheriff's dispatcher
  9 24 receive written notice within six hours of filing the order,
  9 25 approved consent agreement, amendment, or revocation. The
  9 26 clerk may fulfill this requirement by sending the notice by
  9 27 facsimile or other electronic transmission which reproduces the
  9 28 notice in writing within six hours of filing the order.
  9 29    8.  The county sheriff's dispatcher shall notify all law
  9 30 enforcement agencies having jurisdiction over the matter
  9 31 and the twenty=four=hour dispatcher for the law enforcement
  9 32 agencies upon notification by the clerk.
  9 33    Sec. 21.    8 35 if the court, after hearing at which the defendant has the
  9  1 opportunity to be heard, finds that the defendant continues to
  9  2 pose a threat to the safety of the victim, persons residing
  9  3 with the victim, or members of the victim's immediate family.
  9  4 The number of extensions that can be granted by the court is
  9  5 not limited.

  9 27 facsimile or other electronic transmission which reproduces the
  9 28 notice in writing within six hours of filing the order.
  9 29    8.  The county sheriff's dispatcher shall notify all law
  9 30 enforcement agencies having jurisdiction over the matter
  9 31 and the twenty=four=hour dispatcher for the law enforcement
  9 32 agencies upon notification by the clerk.
  9 33    Sec. 21.    9 20 a copy of the order or consent agreement.
  9 21    7.  The clerk shall notify the county sheriff and the
  9 22 twenty=four=hour dispatcher for the county sheriff in writing
  9 23 so that the county sheriff and the county sheriff's dispatcher
  9 24 receive written notice within six hours of filing the order,
  9 25 approved consent agreement, amendment, or revocation. The
  9 26 clerk may fulfill this requirement by sending the notice by
  9 27 facsimile or other electronic transmission which reproduces the
  9 28 notice in writing within six hours of filing the order.
  9 29    8.  The county sheriff's dispatcher shall notify all law
  9 30 enforcement agencies having jurisdiction over the matter
  9 31 and the twenty=four=hour dispatcher for the law enforcement
  9 32 agencies upon notification by the clerk.

  9 33    Sec. 21.    9 33    Sec. 21.    9 34    1.  When the court is unavailable from the close of business
  9 35 at the end of the day or week to the resumption of business at
 10  1 the beginning of the next day or week, a petition may be filed
 10  2 before a district judge, or district associate judge designated
 10  3 by the chief judge of the judicial district, who may grant
 10  4 emergency relief in accordance with section 236A.7, subsection
 10  5 1, paragraph "b", if the district judge or district associate
 10  6 judge deems it necessary to protect the plaintiff from dating
 10  7 abuse, upon good cause shown in an ex parte proceeding.
 10  8 Present danger of dating abuse to the plaintiff constitutes
 10  9 good cause for purposes of this subsection.
 10 10    2.  An emergency order issued under subsection 1 shall expire
 10 11 seventy=two hours after issuance. When the order expires, the
 10 12 plaintiff may seek a temporary order from the court pursuant
 10 13 to section 236A.6.
 10 14    3.  A petition filed and emergency order issued under this
 10 15 section and any documentation in support of the petition
 10 16 and order shall be immediately certified to the court. The
 10 17 certification shall commence a proceeding for purposes of
 10 18 section 236A.3.
 10 19    Sec. 22.    9 35 at the end of the day or week to the resumption of business at
 10  1 the beginning of the next day or week, a petition may be filed
 10  2 before a district judge, or district associate judge designated
 10  3 by the chief judge of the judicial district, who may grant
 10  4 emergency relief in accordance with section 236A.7, subsection
 10  5 1, paragraph "b", if the district judge or district associate
 10  6 judge deems it necessary to protect the plaintiff from dating
 10  7 abuse, upon good cause shown in an ex parte proceeding.

 10 19    Sec. 22.   10 19    Sec. 22.   10 20    A proceeding under this chapter shall be held in accordance
 10 21 with the rules of civil procedure, except as otherwise set
 10 22 forth in this chapter and in chapter 664A, and is in addition
 10 23 to any other civil or criminal remedy.
 10 24    Sec. 23.   10 21 with the rules of civil procedure, except as otherwise set
 10 22 forth in this chapter and in chapter 664A, and is in addition
 10 23 to any other civil or criminal remedy.
 10 24    Sec. 23.   10 22 forth in this chapter and in chapter 664A, and is in addition
 10 23 to any other civil or criminal remedy.
 10 24    Sec. 23.   10 23 to any other civil or criminal remedy.
 10 24    Sec. 23.   10 24    Sec. 23.   10 25    1.  Criminal or juvenile justice agencies, as defined
 10 26 in section 692.1, shall collect and maintain information
 10 27 on incidents involving dating abuse and shall provide the
 10 28 information to the department of public safety in the manner
 10 29 prescribed by the department of public safety.
 10 30    2.  The department of public safety may compile statistics
 10 31 and issue reports on dating abuse in Iowa, provided individual
 10 32 identifying details of the dating abuse are deleted. The
 10 33 statistics and reports may include nonidentifying information
 10 34 on the personal characteristics of perpetrators and victims.
 10 35 The department of public safety may request the cooperation
 11  1 of the department of justice in compiling the statistics and
 11  2 issuing the reports. The department of public safety may
 11  3 provide nonidentifying information on individual incidents
 11  4 of dating abuse to persons conducting bona fide research,
 11  5 including but not limited to personnel of the department of
 11  6 justice.
 11  7    Sec. 24.   10 26 in section 692.1, shall collect and maintain information
 10 27 on incidents involving dating abuse and shall provide the
 10 28 information to the department of public safety in the manner
 10 29 prescribed by the department of public safety.

 10 31 and issue reports on dating abuse in Iowa, provided individual
 10 32 identifying details of the dating abuse are deleted. The
 10 33 statistics and reports may include nonidentifying information
 10 34 on the personal characteristics of perpetrators and victims.

 11  3 provide nonidentifying information on individual incidents
 11  4 of dating abuse to persons conducting bona fide research,
 11  5 including but not limited to personnel of the department of
 11  6 justice.

 11  7    Sec. 24.   11  6 justice.
 11  7    Sec. 24.   11  7    Sec. 24.   11  8 confidentiality of records.
 11  9    1.  A person seeking relief from dating abuse under this
 11 10 chapter may use any of the following addresses as a mailing
 11 11 address for purposes of filing a petition under this chapter,
 11 12 as well as for the purpose of obtaining any utility or other
 11 13 service:
 11 14    a.  The mailing address of a shelter or other agency.
 11 15    b.  A public or private post office box.
 11 16    c.  Any other mailing address, with the permission of the
 11 17 resident of that address.
 11 18    2.  A person shall report any change of address, whether
 11 19 designated according to subsection 1 or otherwise, to the clerk
 11 20 of court no more than five days after the previous address on
 11 21 record becomes invalid.
 11 22    3.  The entire file or a portion of the file in a dating
 11 23 abuse case shall be sealed by the clerk of court as ordered
 11 24 by the court to protect the privacy interest or safety of any
 11 25 person.
 11 26    4.  Notwithstanding subsection 3, court orders and support
 11 27 payment records shall remain public records, although the court
 11 28 may order that address and location information be redacted
 11 29 from the public records.
 11 30    Sec. 25.   11  9    1.  A person seeking relief from dating abuse under this
 11 10 chapter may use any of the following addresses as a mailing
 11 11 address for purposes of filing a petition under this chapter,
 11 12 as well as for the purpose of obtaining any utility or other
 11 13 service:
 11 14    a.  The mailing address of a shelter or other agency.
 11 15    b.  A public or private post office box.
 11 16    c.  Any other mailing address, with the permission of the
 11 17 resident of that address.
 11 18    2.  A person shall report any change of address, whether
 11 19 designated according to subsection 1 or otherwise, to the clerk
 11 20 of court no more than five days after the previous address on
 11 21 record becomes invalid.
 11 22    3.  The entire file or a portion of the file in a dating
 11 23 abuse case shall be sealed by the clerk of court as ordered
 11 24 by the court to protect the privacy interest or safety of any
 11 25 person.
 11 26    4.  Notwithstanding subsection 3, court orders and support
 11 27 payment records shall remain public records, although the court
 11 28 may order that address and location information be redacted
 11 29 from the public records.
 11 30    Sec. 25.   11 10 chapter may use any of the following addresses as a mailing
 11 11 address for purposes of filing a petition under this chapter,
 11 12 as well as for the purpose of obtaining any utility or other
 11 13 service:
 11 14    a.  The mailing address of a shelter or other agency.
 11 15    b.  A public or private post office box.
 11 16    c.  Any other mailing address, with the permission of the
 11 17 resident of that address.
 11 18    2.  A person shall report any change of address, whether
 11 19 designated according to subsection 1 or otherwise, to the clerk
 11 20 of court no more than five days after the previous address on
 11 21 record becomes invalid.
 11 22    3.  The entire file or a portion of the file in a dating
 11 23 abuse case shall be sealed by the clerk of court as ordered
 11 24 by the court to protect the privacy interest or safety of any
 11 25 person.
 11 26    4.  Notwithstanding subsection 3, court orders and support
 11 27 payment records shall remain public records, although the court
 11 28 may order that address and location information be redacted
 11 29 from the public records.
 11 30    Sec. 25.   11 11 address for purposes of filing a petition under this chapter,
 11 12 as well as for the purpose of obtaining any utility or other
 11 13 service:
 11 14    a.  The mailing address of a shelter or other agency.
 11 15    b.  A public or private post office box.
 11 16    c.  Any other mailing address, with the permission of the
 11 17 resident of that address.
 11 18    2.  A person shall report any change of address, whether
 11 19 designated according to subsection 1 or otherwise, to the clerk
 11 20 of court no more than five days after the previous address on
 11 21 record becomes invalid.
 11 22    3.  The entire file or a portion of the file in a dating
 11 23 abuse case shall be sealed by the clerk of court as ordered
 11 24 by the court to protect the privacy interest or safety of any
 11 25 person.
 11 26    4.  Notwithstanding subsection 3, court orders and support
 11 27 payment records shall remain public records, although the court
 11 28 may order that address and location information be redacted
 11 29 from the public records.
 11 30    Sec. 25.   11 12 as well as for the purpose of obtaining any utility or other
 11 13 service:

 11 17 resident of that address.

 11 27 payment records shall remain public records, although the court
 11 28 may order that address and location information be redacted
 11 29 from the public records.

 11 28 may order that address and location information be redacted
 11 29 from the public records.
 11 30    Sec. 25.   11 28 may order that address and location information be redacted
 11 29 from the public records.
 11 30    Sec. 25.   11 29 from the public records.
 11 30    Sec. 25.   11 30    Sec. 25.   11 31 magistrate.
 11 32    1.  A peace officer shall use every reasonable means to
 11 33 enforce an order or court=approved consent agreement entered
 11 34 under this chapter, an order that establishes conditions
 11 35 of release or is a protective order or sentencing order in
 12  1 a criminal prosecution arising from a dating abuse, or a
 12  2 protective order under chapter 232. If a peace officer has
 12  3 reason to believe that dating abuse has occurred, the peace
 12  4 officer shall ask the abused person if any prior orders
 12  5 exist, and shall contact the twenty=four=hour dispatcher to
 12  6 inquire if any prior orders exist. If a peace officer has
 12  7 probable cause to believe that a person has violated an order
 12  8 or approved consent agreement entered under this chapter,
 12  9 an order establishing conditions of release or a protective
 12 10 or sentencing order in a criminal prosecution arising from
 12 11 dating abuse, or, if the person is an adult, a violation
 12 12 of a protective order under chapter 232, the peace officer
 12 13 shall take the person into custody and shall take the person
 12 14 without unnecessary delay before the nearest or most accessible
 12 15 magistrate in the judicial district in which the person was
 12 16 taken into custody. The magistrate shall make an initial
 12 17 preliminary determination whether there is probable cause to
 12 18 believe that an order or consent agreement existed and that
 12 19 the person taken into custody has violated its terms. The
 12 20 magistrate's decision shall be entered in the record.
 12 21    2.  If a peace officer has probable cause to believe that
 12 22 a person has violated an order or approved consent agreement
 12 23 entered under this chapter, an order establishing conditions
 12 24 of release or a protective or sentencing order in a criminal
 12 25 prosecution arising from dating abuse, or a protective order
 12 26 under chapter 232, and the peace officer is unable to take the
 12 27 person into custody within twenty=four hours of making the
 12 28 probable cause determination, the peace officer shall either
 12 29 request a magistrate to make a determination as to whether a
 12 30 rule to show cause or arrest warrant should be issued, or refer
 12 31 the matter to the county attorney.
 12 32    3.  If the magistrate finds probable cause, the magistrate
 12 33 shall order the person to appear either before the court which
 12 34 issued the original order or approved the consent agreement,
 12 35 or before the court in the jurisdiction where the alleged
 13  1 violation took place, at a specified time not less than
 13  2 five days and not more than fifteen days after the initial
 13  3 appearance under this section. The magistrate shall cause
 13  4 the original court to be notified of the contents of the
 13  5 magistrate's order.
 13  6    4.  A peace officer shall not be held civilly or criminally
 13  7 liable for acting pursuant to this section provided that the
 13  8 peace officer acts reasonably and in good faith, on probable
 13  9 cause, and the officer's acts do not constitute a willful and
 13 10 wanton disregard for the rights or safety of another.
 13 11    Sec. 26.   11 32    1.  A peace officer shall use every reasonable means to
 11 33 enforce an order or court=approved consent agreement entered
 11 34 under this chapter, an order that establishes conditions
 11 35 of release or is a protective order or sentencing order in
 12  1 a criminal prosecution arising from a dating abuse, or a
 12  2 protective order under chapter 232. If a peace officer has
 12  3 reason to believe that dating abuse has occurred, the peace
 12  4 officer shall ask the abused person if any prior orders
 12  5 exist, and shall contact the twenty=four=hour dispatcher to
 12  6 inquire if any prior orders exist. If a peace officer has
 12  7 probable cause to believe that a person has violated an order
 12  8 or approved consent agreement entered under this chapter,

 12 11 dating abuse, or, if the person is an adult, a violation
 12 12 of a protective order under chapter 232, the peace officer
 12 13 shall take the person into custody and shall take the person
 12 14 without unnecessary delay before the nearest or most accessible
 12 15 magistrate in the judicial district in which the person was
 12 16 taken into custody. The magistrate shall make an initial
 12 17 preliminary determination whether there is probable cause to
 12 18 believe that an order or consent agreement existed and that
 12 19 the person taken into custody has violated its terms. The
 12 20 magistrate's decision shall be entered in the record.
 12 21    2.  If a peace officer has probable cause to believe that
 12 22 a person has violated an order or approved consent agreement
 12 23 entered under this chapter, an order establishing conditions
 12 24 of release or a protective or sentencing order in a criminal
 12 25 prosecution arising from dating abuse, or a protective order
 12 26 under chapter 232, and the peace officer is unable to take the
 12 27 person into custody within twenty=four hours of making the
 12 28 probable cause determination, the peace officer shall either
 12 29 request a magistrate to make a determination as to whether a
 12 30 rule to show cause or arrest warrant should be issued, or refer
 12 31 the matter to the county attorney.
 12 32    3.  If the magistrate finds probable cause, the magistrate
 12 33 shall order the person to appear either before the court which
 12 34 issued the original order or approved the consent agreement,
 12 35 or before the court in the jurisdiction where the alleged
 13  1 violation took place, at a specified time not less than
 13  2 five days and not more than fifteen days after the initial
 13  3 appearance under this section. The magistrate shall cause
 13  4 the original court to be notified of the contents of the
 13  5 magistrate's order.
 13  6    4.  A peace officer shall not be held civilly or criminally
 13  7 liable for acting pursuant to this section provided that the
 13  8 peace officer acts reasonably and in good faith, on probable
 13  9 cause, and the officer's acts do not constitute a willful and
 13 10 wanton disregard for the rights or safety of another.

 12 27 person into custody within twenty=four hours of making the
 12 28 probable cause determination, the peace officer shall either
 12 29 request a magistrate to make a determination as to whether a
 12 30 rule to show cause or arrest warrant should be issued, or refer
 12 31 the matter to the county attorney.
 12 32    3.  If the magistrate finds probable cause, the magistrate
 12 33 shall order the person to appear either before the court which
 12 34 issued the original order or approved the consent agreement,
 12 35 or before the court in the jurisdiction where the alleged
 13  1 violation took place, at a specified time not less than
 13  2 five days and not more than fifteen days after the initial
 13  3 appearance under this section. The magistrate shall cause
 13  4 the original court to be notified of the contents of the
 13  5 magistrate's order.
 13  6    4.  A peace officer shall not be held civilly or criminally
 13  7 liable for acting pursuant to this section provided that the
 13  8 peace officer acts reasonably and in good faith, on probable
 13  9 cause, and the officer's acts do not constitute a willful and
 13 10 wanton disregard for the rights or safety of another.
 13 11    Sec. 26.   12  4 officer shall ask the abused person if any prior orders
 12  5 exist, and shall contact the twenty=four=hour dispatcher to
 12  6 inquire if any prior orders exist. If a peace officer has
 12  7 probable cause to believe that a person has violated an order
 12  8 or approved consent agreement entered under this chapter,
 12  9 an order establishing conditions of release or a protective
 12 10 or sentencing order in a criminal prosecution arising from
 12 11 dating abuse, or, if the person is an adult, a violation
 12 12 of a protective order under chapter 232, the peace officer
 12 13 shall take the person into custody and shall take the person
 12 14 without unnecessary delay before the nearest or most accessible
 12 15 magistrate in the judicial district in which the person was
 12 16 taken into custody. The magistrate shall make an initial
 12 17 preliminary determination whether there is probable cause to
 12 18 believe that an order or consent agreement existed and that
 12 19 the person taken into custody has violated its terms. The
 12 20 magistrate's decision shall be entered in the record.
 12 21    2.  If a peace officer has probable cause to believe that
 12 22 a person has violated an order or approved consent agreement
 12 23 entered under this chapter, an order establishing conditions
 12 24 of release or a protective or sentencing order in a criminal
 12 25 prosecution arising from dating abuse, or a protective order
 12 26 under chapter 232, and the peace officer is unable to take the
 12 27 person into custody within twenty=four hours of making the
 12 28 probable cause determination, the peace officer shall either
 12 29 request a magistrate to make a determination as to whether a
 12 30 rule to show cause or arrest warrant should be issued, or refer
 12 31 the matter to the county attorney.

 13  2 five days and not more than fifteen days after the initial
 13  3 appearance under this section. The magistrate shall cause
 13  4 the original court to be notified of the contents of the
 13  5 magistrate's order.

 13  8 peace officer acts reasonably and in good faith, on probable
 13  9 cause, and the officer's acts do not constitute a willful and
 13 10 wanton disregard for the rights or safety of another.
 13 11    Sec. 26.   12 19 the person taken into custody has violated its terms. The
 12 20 magistrate's decision shall be entered in the record.
 12 21    2.  If a peace officer has probable cause to believe that
 12 22 a person has violated an order or approved consent agreement
 12 23 entered under this chapter, an order establishing conditions
 12 24 of release or a protective or sentencing order in a criminal
 12 25 prosecution arising from dating abuse, or a protective order
 12 26 under chapter 232, and the peace officer is unable to take the
 12 27 person into custody within twenty=four hours of making the
 12 28 probable cause determination, the peace officer shall either
 12 29 request a magistrate to make a determination as to whether a
 12 30 rule to show cause or arrest warrant should be issued, or refer
 12 31 the matter to the county attorney.
 12 32    3.  If the magistrate finds probable cause, the magistrate
 12 33 shall order the person to appear either before the court which
 12 34 issued the original order or approved the consent agreement,
 12 35 or before the court in the jurisdiction where the alleged
 13  1 violation took place, at a specified time not less than
 13  2 five days and not more than fifteen days after the initial
 13  3 appearance under this section. The magistrate shall cause
 13  4 the original court to be notified of the contents of the
 13  5 magistrate's order.
 13  6    4.  A peace officer shall not be held civilly or criminally
 13  7 liable for acting pursuant to this section provided that the
 13  8 peace officer acts reasonably and in good faith, on probable
 13  9 cause, and the officer's acts do not constitute a willful and
 13 10 wanton disregard for the rights or safety of another.

 13 11    Sec. 26.   13  9 cause, and the officer's acts do not constitute a willful and

 13 11    Sec. 26.   13 10 wanton disregard for the rights or safety of another.
 13 11    Sec. 26.   13 11    Sec. 26.   13 12 ==== notification of rights ==== arrest ==== liability.
 13 13    1.  If a peace officer has reason to believe that dating
 13 14 abuse has occurred, the officer shall use all reasonable means
 13 15 to prevent further abuse including but not limited to the
 13 16 following:
 13 17    a.  If requested, remaining on the scene as long as there
 13 18 is a danger to an abused person's physical safety without the
 13 19 presence of a peace officer, including but not limited to
 13 20 staying in the residence, or if unable to remain on the scene,
 13 21 assisting the person in leaving the residence.
 13 22    b.  Assisting an abused person in obtaining medical treatment
 13 23 necessitated by an assault, including providing assistance to
 13 24 the abused person in obtaining transportation to the emergency
 13 25 room of the nearest hospital.
 13 26    c.  Providing an abused person with immediate and adequate
 13 27 notice of the person's rights. The notice shall consist of
 13 28 handing the person a document that includes the telephone
 13 29 numbers of shelters, support groups, and crisis lines operating
 13 30 in the area and contains a copy of the following statement
 13 31 written in English and Spanish; asking the person to read the
 13 32 card; and asking whether the person understands the rights:
 13 33    You have the right to ask the court for the following help on
 13 34 a temporary basis:
 13 35    [1]  Keeping your attacker away from you, your home, and your
 14  1 place of work.
 14  2    [2]  The right to stay at your home without interference from
 14  3 your attacker.
 14  4    You have the right to seek help from the court to seek
 14  5 a protective order with or without the assistance of legal
 14  6 representation. You have the right to seek help from the
 14  7 courts without the payment of court costs if you do not have
 14  8 sufficient funds to pay the costs.
 14  9    You have the right to file criminal charges for threats,
 14 10 assaults, or other related crimes.
 14 11    You have the right to seek restitution against your attacker
 14 12 for harm to yourself or your property.
 14 13    If you are in need of medical treatment, you have the right
 14 14 to request that the officer present assist you in obtaining
 14 15 transportation to the nearest hospital or otherwise assist you.
 14 16    If you believe that police protection is needed for your
 14 17 physical safety, you have the right to request that the officer
 14 18 present remain at the scene until you and other affected
 14 19 parties can leave or until safety is otherwise ensured.
 14 20    2.  A peace officer is not civilly or criminally liable for
 14 21 actions pursuant to this section taken reasonably and in good
 14 22 faith.
 14 23    Sec. 27.   13 13    1.  If a peace officer has reason to believe that dating
 13 14 abuse has occurred, the officer shall use all reasonable means
 13 15 to prevent further abuse including but not limited to the
 13 16 following:
 13 17    a.  If requested, remaining on the scene as long as there
 13 18 is a danger to an abused person's physical safety without the
 13 19 presence of a peace officer, including but not limited to
 13 20 staying in the residence, or if unable to remain on the scene,
 13 21 assisting the person in leaving the residence.
 13 22    b.  Assisting an abused person in obtaining medical treatment
 13 23 necessitated by an assault, including providing assistance to
 13 24 the abused person in obtaining transportation to the emergency
 13 25 room of the nearest hospital.
 13 26    c.  Providing an abused person with immediate and adequate
 13 27 notice of the person's rights. The notice shall consist of
 13 28 handing the person a document that includes the telephone
 13 29 numbers of shelters, support groups, and crisis lines operating
 13 30 in the area and contains a copy of the following statement
 13 31 written in English and Spanish; asking the person to read the
 13 32 card; and asking whether the person understands the rights:
 13 33    You have the right to ask the court for the following help on
 13 34 a temporary basis:
 13 35    [1]  Keeping your attacker away from you, your home, and your
 14  1 place of work.
 14  2    [2]  The right to stay at your home without interference from
 14  3 your attacker.
 14  4    You have the right to seek help from the court to seek
 14  5 a protective order with or without the assistance of legal
 14  6 representation. You have the right to seek help from the
 14  7 courts without the payment of court costs if you do not have
 14  8 sufficient funds to pay the costs.
 14  9    You have the right to file criminal charges for threats,
 14 10 assaults, or other related crimes.
 14 11    You have the right to seek restitution against your attacker
 14 12 for harm to yourself or your property.
 14 13    If you are in need of medical treatment, you have the right
 14 14 to request that the officer present assist you in obtaining
 14 15 transportation to the nearest hospital or otherwise assist you.
 14 16    If you believe that police protection is needed for your
 14 17 physical safety, you have the right to request that the officer
 14 18 present remain at the scene until you and other affected
 14 19 parties can leave or until safety is otherwise ensured.
 14 20    2.  A peace officer is not civilly or criminally liable for
 14 21 actions pursuant to this section taken reasonably and in good
 14 22 faith.
 14 23    Sec. 27.   13 14 abuse has occurred, the officer shall use all reasonable means
 13 15 to prevent further abuse including but not limited to the
 13 16 following:
 13 17    a.  If requested, remaining on the scene as long as there
 13 18 is a danger to an abused person's physical safety without the
 13 19 presence of a peace officer, including but not limited to
 13 20 staying in the residence, or if unable to remain on the scene,
 13 21 assisting the person in leaving the residence.
 13 22    b.  Assisting an abused person in obtaining medical treatment
 13 23 necessitated by an assault, including providing assistance to
 13 24 the abused person in obtaining transportation to the emergency
 13 25 room of the nearest hospital.
 13 26    c.  Providing an abused person with immediate and adequate
 13 27 notice of the person's rights. The notice shall consist of
 13 28 handing the person a document that includes the telephone
 13 29 numbers of shelters, support groups, and crisis lines operating
 13 30 in the area and contains a copy of the following statement
 13 31 written in English and Spanish; asking the person to read the
 13 32 card; and asking whether the person understands the rights:
 13 33    You have the right to ask the court for the following help on
 13 34 a temporary basis:
 13 35    [1]  Keeping your attacker away from you, your home, and your
 14  1 place of work.
 14  2    [2]  The right to stay at your home without interference from
 14  3 your attacker.
 14  4    You have the right to seek help from the court to seek
 14  5 a protective order with or without the assistance of legal
 14  6 representation. You have the right to seek help from the
 14  7 courts without the payment of court costs if you do not have
 14  8 sufficient funds to pay the costs.
 14  9    You have the right to file criminal charges for threats,
 14 10 assaults, or other related crimes.
 14 11    You have the right to seek restitution against your attacker
 14 12 for harm to yourself or your property.
 14 13    If you are in need of medical treatment, you have the right
 14 14 to request that the officer present assist you in obtaining
 14 15 transportation to the nearest hospital or otherwise assist you.
 14 16    If you believe that police protection is needed for your
 14 17 physical safety, you have the right to request that the officer
 14 18 present remain at the scene until you and other affected
 14 19 parties can leave or until safety is otherwise ensured.
 14 20    2.  A peace officer is not civilly or criminally liable for
 14 21 actions pursuant to this section taken reasonably and in good
 14 22 faith.
 14 23    Sec. 27.   13 15 to prevent further abuse including but not limited to the
 13 16 following:
 13 17    a.  If requested, remaining on the scene as long as there
 13 18 is a danger to an abused person's physical safety without the
 13 19 presence of a peace officer, including but not limited to
 13 20 staying in the residence, or if unable to remain on the scene,
 13 21 assisting the person in leaving the residence.
 13 22    b.  Assisting an abused person in obtaining medical treatment
 13 23 necessitated by an assault, including providing assistance to
 13 24 the abused person in obtaining transportation to the emergency
 13 25 room of the nearest hospital.
 13 26    c.  Providing an abused person with immediate and adequate
 13 27 notice of the person's rights. The notice shall consist of
 13 28 handing the person a document that includes the telephone
 13 29 numbers of shelters, support groups, and crisis lines operating
 13 30 in the area and contains a copy of the following statement
 13 31 written in English and Spanish; asking the person to read the
 13 32 card; and asking whether the person understands the rights:
 13 33    You have the right to ask the court for the following help on
 13 34 a temporary basis:
 13 35    [1]  Keeping your attacker away from you, your home, and your
 14  1 place of work.
 14  2    [2]  The right to stay at your home without interference from
 14  3 your attacker.
 14  4    You have the right to seek help from the court to seek
 14  5 a protective order with or without the assistance of legal
 14  6 representation. You have the right to seek help from the
 14  7 courts without the payment of court costs if you do not have
 14  8 sufficient funds to pay the costs.
 14  9    You have the right to file criminal charges for threats,
 14 10 assaults, or other related crimes.
 14 11    You have the right to seek restitution against your attacker
 14 12 for harm to yourself or your property.
 14 13    If you are in need of medical treatment, you have the right
 14 14 to request that the officer present assist you in obtaining
 14 15 transportation to the nearest hospital or otherwise assist you.
 14 16    If you believe that police protection is needed for your
 14 17 physical safety, you have the right to request that the officer
 14 18 present remain at the scene until you and other affected
 14 19 parties can leave or until safety is otherwise ensured.
 14 20    2.  A peace officer is not civilly or criminally liable for
 14 21 actions pursuant to this section taken reasonably and in good
 14 22 faith.
 14 23    Sec. 27.   13 16 following:
 13 17    a.  If requested, remaining on the scene as long as there
 13 18 is a danger to an abused person's physical safety without the
 13 19 presence of a peace officer, including but not limited to
 13 20 staying in the residence, or if unable to remain on the scene,
 13 21 assisting the person in leaving the residence.
 13 22    b.  Assisting an abused person in obtaining medical treatment
 13 23 necessitated by an assault, including providing assistance to
 13 24 the abused person in obtaining transportation to the emergency
 13 25 room of the nearest hospital.
 13 26    c.  Providing an abused person with immediate and adequate
 13 27 notice of the person's rights. The notice shall consist of
 13 28 handing the person a document that includes the telephone
 13 29 numbers of shelters, support groups, and crisis lines operating
 13 30 in the area and contains a copy of the following statement
 13 31 written in English and Spanish; asking the person to read the
 13 32 card; and asking whether the person understands the rights:
 13 33    You have the right to ask the court for the following help on
 13 34 a temporary basis:
 13 35    [1]  Keeping your attacker away from you, your home, and your
 14  1 place of work.
 14  2    [2]  The right to stay at your home without interference from
 14  3 your attacker.
 14  4    You have the right to seek help from the court to seek
 14  5 a protective order with or without the assistance of legal
 14  6 representation. You have the right to seek help from the
 14  7 courts without the payment of court costs if you do not have
 14  8 sufficient funds to pay the costs.
 14  9    You have the right to file criminal charges for threats,
 14 10 assaults, or other related crimes.
 14 11    You have the right to seek restitution against your attacker
 14 12 for harm to yourself or your property.
 14 13    If you are in need of medical treatment, you have the right
 14 14 to request that the officer present assist you in obtaining
 14 15 transportation to the nearest hospital or otherwise assist you.
 14 16    If you believe that police protection is needed for your
 14 17 physical safety, you have the right to request that the officer
 14 18 present remain at the scene until you and other affected
 14 19 parties can leave or until safety is otherwise ensured.
 14 20    2.  A peace officer is not civilly or criminally liable for
 14 21 actions pursuant to this section taken reasonably and in good
 14 22 faith.

 14 11    You have the right to seek restitution against your attacker
 14 12 for harm to yourself or your property.
 14 13    If you are in need of medical treatment, you have the right
 14 14 to request that the officer present assist you in obtaining
 14 15 transportation to the nearest hospital or otherwise assist you.
 14 16    If you believe that police protection is needed for your
 14 17 physical safety, you have the right to request that the officer
 14 18 present remain at the scene until you and other affected
 14 19 parties can leave or until safety is otherwise ensured.
 14 20    2.  A peace officer is not civilly or criminally liable for
 14 21 actions pursuant to this section taken reasonably and in good
 14 22 faith.
 14 23    Sec. 27.   13 31 written in English and Spanish; asking the person to read the
 13 32 card; and asking whether the person understands the rights:
 13 33    You have the right to ask the court for the following help on
 13 34 a temporary basis:
 13 35    [1]  Keeping your attacker away from you, your home, and your
 14  1 place of work.
 14  2    [2]  The right to stay at your home without interference from
 14  3 your attacker.
 14  4    You have the right to seek help from the court to seek
 14  5 a protective order with or without the assistance of legal
 14  6 representation. You have the right to seek help from the
 14  7 courts without the payment of court costs if you do not have
 14  8 sufficient funds to pay the costs.
 14  9    You have the right to file criminal charges for threats,
 14 10 assaults, or other related crimes.
 14 11    You have the right to seek restitution against your attacker
 14 12 for harm to yourself or your property.
 14 13    If you are in need of medical treatment, you have the right
 14 14 to request that the officer present assist you in obtaining
 14 15 transportation to the nearest hospital or otherwise assist you.
 14 16    If you believe that police protection is needed for your
 14 17 physical safety, you have the right to request that the officer
 14 18 present remain at the scene until you and other affected
 14 19 parties can leave or until safety is otherwise ensured.
 14 20    2.  A peace officer is not civilly or criminally liable for
 14 21 actions pursuant to this section taken reasonably and in good
 14 22 faith.

 14 23    Sec. 27.   14 22 faith.
 14 23    Sec. 27.   14 23    Sec. 27.   14 24    In a criminal action arising from dating abuse, the
 14 25 prosecuting attorney or court shall not refer or order the
 14 26 parties involved to mediation or other nonjudicial procedures
 14 27 prior to judicial resolution of the action.
 14 28    Sec. 28.   14 25 prosecuting attorney or court shall not refer or order the
 14 26 parties involved to mediation or other nonjudicial procedures
 14 27 prior to judicial resolution of the action.
 14 28    Sec. 28.   14 26 parties involved to mediation or other nonjudicial procedures
 14 27 prior to judicial resolution of the action.
 14 28    Sec. 28.   14 27 prior to judicial resolution of the action.
 14 28    Sec. 28.   14 28    Sec. 28.   14 29 and funding as a provider of services for victims of dating
 14 30 abuse.
 14 31    Upon receipt of state or federal funding designated for
 14 32 victims of dating abuse by the department, a public or private
 14 33 nonprofit organization may apply to the department for
 14 34 designation and funding as a provider of emergency shelter
 14 35 services and support services to victims of dating abuse. The
 15  1 application shall be submitted on a form prescribed by the
 15  2 department and shall include but not be limited to information
 15  3 regarding services to be provided, budget, and security
 15  4 measures.
 15  5    Sec. 29.   14 30 abuse.
 14 31    Upon receipt of state or federal funding designated for
 14 32 victims of dating abuse by the department, a public or private
 14 33 nonprofit organization may apply to the department for
 14 34 designation and funding as a provider of emergency shelter
 14 35 services and support services to victims of dating abuse. The
 15  1 application shall be submitted on a form prescribed by the
 15  2 department and shall include but not be limited to information
 15  3 regarding services to be provided, budget, and security
 15  4 measures.
 15  5    Sec. 29.   14 31    Upon receipt of state or federal funding designated for
 14 32 victims of dating abuse by the department, a public or private
 14 33 nonprofit organization may apply to the department for
 14 34 designation and funding as a provider of emergency shelter
 14 35 services and support services to victims of dating abuse. The
 15  1 application shall be submitted on a form prescribed by the
 15  2 department and shall include but not be limited to information
 15  3 regarding services to be provided, budget, and security
 15  4 measures.
 15  5    Sec. 29.   14 32 victims of dating abuse by the department, a public or private
 14 33 nonprofit organization may apply to the department for
 14 34 designation and funding as a provider of emergency shelter
 14 35 services and support services to victims of dating abuse. The
 15  1 application shall be submitted on a form prescribed by the
 15  2 department and shall include but not be limited to information
 15  3 regarding services to be provided, budget, and security
 15  4 measures.
 15  5    Sec. 29.   14 33 nonprofit organization may apply to the department for
 14 34 designation and funding as a provider of emergency shelter
 14 35 services and support services to victims of dating abuse. The
 15  1 application shall be submitted on a form prescribed by the
 15  2 department and shall include but not be limited to information
 15  3 regarding services to be provided, budget, and security
 15  4 measures.
 15  5    Sec. 29.   14 34 designation and funding as a provider of emergency shelter
 14 35 services and support services to victims of dating abuse. The
 15  1 application shall be submitted on a form prescribed by the
 15  2 department and shall include but not be limited to information
 15  3 regarding services to be provided, budget, and security
 15  4 measures.
 15  5    Sec. 29.   14 35 services and support services to victims of dating abuse. The
 15  1 application shall be submitted on a form prescribed by the
 15  2 department and shall include but not be limited to information
 15  3 regarding services to be provided, budget, and security
 15  4 measures.
 15  5    Sec. 29.   15  1 application shall be submitted on a form prescribed by the
 15  2 department and shall include but not be limited to information
 15  3 regarding services to be provided, budget, and security
 15  4 measures.
 15  5    Sec. 29.   15  2 department and shall include but not be limited to information
 15  3 regarding services to be provided, budget, and security
 15  4 measures.
 15  5    Sec. 29.   15  3 regarding services to be provided, budget, and security
 15  4 measures.
 15  5    Sec. 29.   15  4 measures.
 15  5    Sec. 29.   15  5    Sec. 29.   15  6    1.  The department shall do all of the following:
 15  7    a.  Designate and award grants for existing and pilot
 15  8 programs pursuant to this chapter to provide emergency shelter
 15  9 services and support services to victims of dating abuse.
 15 10    b.  Design and implement a uniform method of collecting data
 15 11 from dating abuse organizations funded under this chapter.
 15 12    c.  Designate and award moneys for publicizing and staffing
 15 13 a statewide, toll=free telephone hotline for use by victims of
 15 14 dating abuse. The department may award a grant to a public
 15 15 agency or a public or private nonprofit organization for the
 15 16 purpose of operating the hotline. The operation of the hotline
 15 17 shall include informing victims of their rights and of various
 15 18 community services that are available, referring victims to
 15 19 service providers, receiving complaints concerning misconduct
 15 20 by peace officers and encouraging victims to refer such
 15 21 complaints to the office of ombudsman, providing counseling
 15 22 services to victims over the telephone, and providing dating
 15 23 abuse victim advocacy.
 15 24    d.  Advertise the toll=free telephone hotline through the
 15 25 use of public service announcements, billboards, print and
 15 26 broadcast media services, and other appropriate means, and
 15 27 contact media organizations to encourage the provision of free
 15 28 or inexpensive advertising concerning the hotline and its
 15 29 services.
 15 30    e.  Develop, with the assistance of the entity operating
 15 31 the telephone hotline and other dating abuse victim services
 15 32 providers, brochures explaining the rights of victims set
 15 33 forth under section 236A.13 and the services of the telephone
 15 34 hotline, and distribute the brochures to law enforcement
 15 35 agencies, victim service providers, health practitioners,
 16  1 charitable and religious organizations, and other entities that
 16  2 may have contact with victims of dating abuse.
 16  3    2.  The department shall consult and cooperate with
 16  4 all public and private agencies that may provide services
 16  5 to victims of dating abuse, including but not limited to
 16  6 legal services, social services, prospective employment
 16  7 opportunities, and unemployment benefits.
 16  8    3.  The department may accept, use, and dispose of
 16  9 contributions of money, services, and property made available
 16 10 by an agency or department of the state or federal government,
 16 11 or a private agency or individual.
 16 12    Sec. 30.   15  7    a.  Designate and award grants for existing and pilot
 15  8 programs pursuant to this chapter to provide emergency shelter
 15  9 services and support services to victims of dating abuse.
 15 10    b.  Design and implement a uniform method of collecting data
 15 11 from dating abuse organizations funded under this chapter.
 15 12    c.  Designate and award moneys for publicizing and staffing
 15 13 a statewide, toll=free telephone hotline for use by victims of
 15 14 dating abuse. The department may award a grant to a public
 15 15 agency or a public or private nonprofit organization for the
 15 16 purpose of operating the hotline. The operation of the hotline
 15 17 shall include informing victims of their rights and of various
 15 18 community services that are available, referring victims to
 15 19 service providers, receiving complaints concerning misconduct
 15 20 by peace officers and encouraging victims to refer such
 15 21 complaints to the office of ombudsman, providing counseling
 15 22 services to victims over the telephone, and providing dating
 15 23 abuse victim advocacy.
 15 24    d.  Advertise the toll=free telephone hotline through the
 15 25 use of public service announcements, billboards, print and
 15 26 broadcast media services, and other appropriate means, and
 15 27 contact media organizations to encourage the provision of free
 15 28 or inexpensive advertising concerning the hotline and its
 15 29 services.
 15 30    e.  Develop, with the assistance of the entity operating
 15 31 the telephone hotline and other dating abuse victim services
 15 32 providers, brochures explaining the rights of victims set
 15 33 forth under section 236A.13 and the services of the telephone
 15 34 hotline, and distribute the brochures to law enforcement
 15 35 agencies, victim service providers, health practitioners,
 16  1 charitable and religious organizations, and other entities that
 16  2 may have contact with victims of dating abuse.
 16  3    2.  The department shall consult and cooperate with
 16  4 all public and private agencies that may provide services
 16  5 to victims of dating abuse, including but not limited to
 16  6 legal services, social services, prospective employment
 16  7 opportunities, and unemployment benefits.
 16  8    3.  The department may accept, use, and dispose of
 16  9 contributions of money, services, and property made available
 16 10 by an agency or department of the state or federal government,
 16 11 or a private agency or individual.
 16 12    Sec. 30.   15  8 programs pursuant to this chapter to provide emergency shelter
 15  9 services and support services to victims of dating abuse.
 15 10    b.  Design and implement a uniform method of collecting data
 15 11 from dating abuse organizations funded under this chapter.
 15 12    c.  Designate and award moneys for publicizing and staffing
 15 13 a statewide, toll=free telephone hotline for use by victims of
 15 14 dating abuse. The department may award a grant to a public
 15 15 agency or a public or private nonprofit organization for the
 15 16 purpose of operating the hotline. The operation of the hotline
 15 17 shall include informing victims of their rights and of various
 15 18 community services that are available, referring victims to
 15 19 service providers, receiving complaints concerning misconduct
 15 20 by peace officers and encouraging victims to refer such
 15 21 complaints to the office of ombudsman, providing counseling
 15 22 services to victims over the telephone, and providing dating
 15 23 abuse victim advocacy.
 15 24    d.  Advertise the toll=free telephone hotline through the
 15 25 use of public service announcements, billboards, print and
 15 26 broadcast media services, and other appropriate means, and
 15 27 contact media organizations to encourage the provision of free
 15 28 or inexpensive advertising concerning the hotline and its
 15 29 services.
 15 30    e.  Develop, with the assistance of the entity operating
 15 31 the telephone hotline and other dating abuse victim services
 15 32 providers, brochures explaining the rights of victims set
 15 33 forth under section 236A.13 and the services of the telephone
 15 34 hotline, and distribute the brochures to law enforcement
 15 35 agencies, victim service providers, health practitioners,
 16  1 charitable and religious organizations, and other entities that
 16  2 may have contact with victims of dating abuse.
 16  3    2.  The department shall consult and cooperate with
 16  4 all public and private agencies that may provide services
 16  5 to victims of dating abuse, including but not limited to
 16  6 legal services, social services, prospective employment
 16  7 opportunities, and unemployment benefits.
 16  8    3.  The department may accept, use, and dispose of
 16  9 contributions of money, services, and property made available
 16 10 by an agency or department of the state or federal government,
 16 11 or a private agency or individual.

 16  8    3.  The department may accept, use, and dispose of
 16  9 contributions of money, services, and property made available
 16 10 by an agency or department of the state or federal government,
 16 11 or a private agency or individual.
 16 12    Sec. 30.   15 27 contact media organizations to encourage the provision of free
 15 28 or inexpensive advertising concerning the hotline and its
 15 29 services.
 15 30    e.  Develop, with the assistance of the entity operating
 15 31 the telephone hotline and other dating abuse victim services
 15 32 providers, brochures explaining the rights of victims set
 15 33 forth under section 236A.13 and the services of the telephone
 15 34 hotline, and distribute the brochures to law enforcement
 15 35 agencies, victim service providers, health practitioners,
 16  1 charitable and religious organizations, and other entities that
 16  2 may have contact with victims of dating abuse.
 16  3    2.  The department shall consult and cooperate with
 16  4 all public and private agencies that may provide services
 16  5 to victims of dating abuse, including but not limited to
 16  6 legal services, social services, prospective employment
 16  7 opportunities, and unemployment benefits.

 16  9 contributions of money, services, and property made available
 16 10 by an agency or department of the state or federal government,
 16 11 or a private agency or individual.
