 16 12    Sec. 30.   16 12    Sec. 30.   16 13 requirements.
 16 14    The department, in cooperation with victim service
 16 15 providers, shall work with various professional organizations
 16 16 to encourage organizations to establish training programs for
 16 17 professionals who work in the area of dating abuse prevention
 16 18 and services. Dating abuse training may include but is not
 16 19 limited to the following areas:
 16 20    1.  The enforcement of both civil and criminal remedies in
 16 21 dating abuse matters.
 16 22    2.  The nature, extent, and causes of dating abuse.
 16 23    3.  The legal rights and remedies available to dating abuse
 16 24 victims, including crime victim compensation.
 16 25    4.  Services available to dating abuse victims including the
 16 26 dating abuse telephone hotline.
 16 27    5.  The duties of peace officers under this chapter.
 16 28    6.  Techniques for intervention in dating abuse cases.
 16 29    Sec. 31.   16 14    The department, in cooperation with victim service
 16 15 providers, shall work with various professional organizations
 16 16 to encourage organizations to establish training programs for
 16 17 professionals who work in the area of dating abuse prevention
 16 18 and services. Dating abuse training may include but is not
 16 19 limited to the following areas:
 16 20    1.  The enforcement of both civil and criminal remedies in
 16 21 dating abuse matters.
 16 22    2.  The nature, extent, and causes of dating abuse.
 16 23    3.  The legal rights and remedies available to dating abuse
 16 24 victims, including crime victim compensation.
 16 25    4.  Services available to dating abuse victims including the
 16 26 dating abuse telephone hotline.
 16 27    5.  The duties of peace officers under this chapter.
 16 28    6.  Techniques for intervention in dating abuse cases.
 16 29    Sec. 31.   16 15 providers, shall work with various professional organizations
 16 16 to encourage organizations to establish training programs for
 16 17 professionals who work in the area of dating abuse prevention
 16 18 and services. Dating abuse training may include but is not
 16 19 limited to the following areas:

 16 21 dating abuse matters.

 16 29    Sec. 31.   16 29    Sec. 31.   16 30 provisions.
 16 31    In addition to the provisions contained in this chapter,
 16 32 certain criminal penalties and provisions pertaining to dating
 16 33 abuse are set forth in chapters 664A and 709 and sections 726.2
 16 34 and 728.12.
 16 35    Sec. 32.   16 31    In addition to the provisions contained in this chapter,
 16 32 certain criminal penalties and provisions pertaining to dating
 16 33 abuse are set forth in chapters 664A and 709 and sections 726.2
 16 34 and 728.12.
 16 35    Sec. 32.   16 32 certain criminal penalties and provisions pertaining to dating
 16 33 abuse are set forth in chapters 664A and 709 and sections 726.2
 16 34 and 728.12.
 16 35    Sec. 32.   16 33 abuse are set forth in chapters 664A and 709 and sections 726.2
 16 34 and 728.12.
 16 35    Sec. 32.   16 34 and 728.12.
 16 35    Sec. 32.   16 35    Sec. 32.   17  1 ==== registration ==== enforcement.
 17  2    1.  As used in this section, "foreign protective order" means
 17  3 a protective order entered by a court of another state, Indian
 17  4 tribe, or United States territory that would be an order or
 17  5 court=approved consent agreement entered under this chapter, an
 17  6 order that establishes conditions of release, or a protective
 17  7 order or sentencing order in a criminal prosecution arising
 17  8 from dating abuse if it had been entered in Iowa.
 17  9    2.  A certified or authenticated copy of a permanent foreign
 17 10 protective order may be filed with the clerk of the district
 17 11 court in any county that would have venue if the original
 17 12 action was being commenced in this state or in which the person
 17 13 in whose favor the order was entered may be present.
 17 14    a.  The clerk shall file foreign protective orders that are
 17 15 not certified or authenticated, if supported by an affidavit of
 17 16 a person with personal knowledge, subject to the penalties for
 17 17 perjury. The person protected by the order may provide this
 17 18 affidavit.
 17 19    b.  The clerk shall provide copies of the order as required
 17 20 by section 236A.7, except that notice shall not be provided to
 17 21 the respondent without the express written direction of the
 17 22 person in whose favor the order was entered.
 17 23    3.  a.  A valid foreign protective order has the same effect
 17 24 and shall be enforced in the same manner as a protective order
 17 25 issued in this state whether or not filed with the clerk of the
 17 26 district court or otherwise placed in a registry of protective
 17 27 orders.
 17 28    b.  A foreign protective order is valid if it meets all of
 17 29 the following:
 17 30    (1)  The order states the name of the protected individual
 17 31 and the individual against whom enforcement is sought.
 17 32    (2)  The order has not expired.
 17 33    (3)  The order was issued by a court or tribunal that had
 17 34 jurisdiction over the parties and subject matter under the law
 17 35 of the foreign jurisdiction.
 18  1    (4)  The order was issued in accordance with the respondent's
 18  2 due process rights, either after the respondent was provided
 18  3 with reasonable notice and an opportunity to be heard before
 18  4 the court or tribunal that issued the order, or in the case
 18  5 of an ex parte order, the respondent was granted notice and
 18  6 opportunity to be heard within a reasonable time after the
 18  7 order was issued.
 18  8    c.  Proof that a foreign protective order failed to meet all
 18  9 of the factors listed in paragraph "b" shall be an affirmative
 18 10 defense in any action seeking enforcement of the order.
 18 11    4.  A peace officer shall treat a foreign protective order as
 18 12 a valid legal document and shall make an arrest for a violation
 18 13 of the foreign protective order in the same manner that a peace
 18 14 officer would make an arrest for a violation of a protective
 18 15 order issued within this state.
 18 16    a.  The fact that a foreign protective order has not been
 18 17 filed with the clerk of the district court or otherwise placed
 18 18 in a registry shall not be grounds to refuse to enforce the
 18 19 terms of the order unless it is apparent to the officer that
 18 20 the order is invalid on its face.
 18 21    b.  A peace officer acting reasonably and in good faith in
 18 22 connection with the enforcement of a foreign protective order
 18 23 shall be immune from civil and criminal liability in any action
 18 24 arising in connection with such enforcement.
 18 25    5.  Filing and service costs in connection with foreign
 18 26 protective orders are waived as provided in section 236A.3.
 18 27    Sec. 33.   17  2    1.  As used in this section, "foreign protective order" means
 17  3 a protective order entered by a court of another state, Indian
 17  4 tribe, or United States territory that would be an order or
 17  5 court=approved consent agreement entered under this chapter, an
 17  6 order that establishes conditions of release, or a protective
 17  7 order or sentencing order in a criminal prosecution arising
 17  8 from dating abuse if it had been entered in Iowa.
 17  9    2.  A certified or authenticated copy of a permanent foreign
 17 10 protective order may be filed with the clerk of the district
 17 11 court in any county that would have venue if the original
 17 12 action was being commenced in this state or in which the person
 17 13 in whose favor the order was entered may be present.
 17 14    a.  The clerk shall file foreign protective orders that are
 17 15 not certified or authenticated, if supported by an affidavit of
 17 16 a person with personal knowledge, subject to the penalties for
 17 17 perjury. The person protected by the order may provide this
 17 18 affidavit.

 17 22 person in whose favor the order was entered.

 17 27 orders.

 17 29 the following:

 17 34 jurisdiction over the parties and subject matter under the law
 17 35 of the foreign jurisdiction.

 18  2 due process rights, either after the respondent was provided
 18  3 with reasonable notice and an opportunity to be heard before
 18  4 the court or tribunal that issued the order, or in the case
 18  5 of an ex parte order, the respondent was granted notice and
 18  6 opportunity to be heard within a reasonable time after the
 18  7 order was issued.
 18  8    c.  Proof that a foreign protective order failed to meet all
 18  9 of the factors listed in paragraph "b" shall be an affirmative
 18 10 defense in any action seeking enforcement of the order.

 18 12 a valid legal document and shall make an arrest for a violation
 18 13 of the foreign protective order in the same manner that a peace
 18 14 officer would make an arrest for a violation of a protective
 18 15 order issued within this state.

 18 17 filed with the clerk of the district court or otherwise placed
 18 18 in a registry shall not be grounds to refuse to enforce the
 18 19 terms of the order unless it is apparent to the officer that
 18 20 the order is invalid on its face.

 18 22 connection with the enforcement of a foreign protective order
 18 23 shall be immune from civil and criminal liability in any action
 18 24 arising in connection with such enforcement.
 18 25    5.  Filing and service costs in connection with foreign
 18 26 protective orders are waived as provided in section 236A.3.

 18 12 a valid legal document and shall make an arrest for a violation
 18 13 of the foreign protective order in the same manner that a peace
 18 14 officer would make an arrest for a violation of a protective
 18 15 order issued within this state.
 18 16    a.  The fact that a foreign protective order has not been
 18 17 filed with the clerk of the district court or otherwise placed
 18 18 in a registry shall not be grounds to refuse to enforce the
 18 19 terms of the order unless it is apparent to the officer that
 18 20 the order is invalid on its face.
 18 21    b.  A peace officer acting reasonably and in good faith in
 18 22 connection with the enforcement of a foreign protective order
 18 23 shall be immune from civil and criminal liability in any action
 18 24 arising in connection with such enforcement.
 18 25    5.  Filing and service costs in connection with foreign
 18 26 protective orders are waived as provided in section 236A.3.
 18 27    Sec. 33.   17  4 tribe, or United States territory that would be an order or
 17  5 court=approved consent agreement entered under this chapter, an
 17  6 order that establishes conditions of release, or a protective
 17  7 order or sentencing order in a criminal prosecution arising
 17  8 from dating abuse if it had been entered in Iowa.
 17  9    2.  A certified or authenticated copy of a permanent foreign
 17 10 protective order may be filed with the clerk of the district
 17 11 court in any county that would have venue if the original
 17 12 action was being commenced in this state or in which the person
 17 13 in whose favor the order was entered may be present.
 17 14    a.  The clerk shall file foreign protective orders that are
 17 15 not certified or authenticated, if supported by an affidavit of
 17 16 a person with personal knowledge, subject to the penalties for
 17 17 perjury. The person protected by the order may provide this
 17 18 affidavit.
 17 19    b.  The clerk shall provide copies of the order as required
 17 20 by section 236A.7, except that notice shall not be provided to
 17 21 the respondent without the express written direction of the
 17 22 person in whose favor the order was entered.
 17 23    3.  a.  A valid foreign protective order has the same effect
 17 24 and shall be enforced in the same manner as a protective order
 17 25 issued in this state whether or not filed with the clerk of the
 17 26 district court or otherwise placed in a registry of protective
 17 27 orders.
 17 28    b.  A foreign protective order is valid if it meets all of
 17 29 the following:
 17 30    (1)  The order states the name of the protected individual
 17 31 and the individual against whom enforcement is sought.
 17 32    (2)  The order has not expired.
 17 33    (3)  The order was issued by a court or tribunal that had
 17 34 jurisdiction over the parties and subject matter under the law
 17 35 of the foreign jurisdiction.
 18  1    (4)  The order was issued in accordance with the respondent's
 18  2 due process rights, either after the respondent was provided
 18  3 with reasonable notice and an opportunity to be heard before
 18  4 the court or tribunal that issued the order, or in the case
 18  5 of an ex parte order, the respondent was granted notice and
 18  6 opportunity to be heard within a reasonable time after the
 18  7 order was issued.
 18  8    c.  Proof that a foreign protective order failed to meet all
 18  9 of the factors listed in paragraph "b" shall be an affirmative
 18 10 defense in any action seeking enforcement of the order.
 18 11    4.  A peace officer shall treat a foreign protective order as
 18 12 a valid legal document and shall make an arrest for a violation
 18 13 of the foreign protective order in the same manner that a peace
 18 14 officer would make an arrest for a violation of a protective
 18 15 order issued within this state.

 18 10 defense in any action seeking enforcement of the order.
 18 11    4.  A peace officer shall treat a foreign protective order as
 18 12 a valid legal document and shall make an arrest for a violation
 18 13 of the foreign protective order in the same manner that a peace
 18 14 officer would make an arrest for a violation of a protective
 18 15 order issued within this state.
 18 16    a.  The fact that a foreign protective order has not been
 18 17 filed with the clerk of the district court or otherwise placed
 18 18 in a registry shall not be grounds to refuse to enforce the
 18 19 terms of the order unless it is apparent to the officer that
 18 20 the order is invalid on its face.
 18 21    b.  A peace officer acting reasonably and in good faith in
 18 22 connection with the enforcement of a foreign protective order
 18 23 shall be immune from civil and criminal liability in any action
 18 24 arising in connection with such enforcement.
 18 25    5.  Filing and service costs in connection with foreign
 18 26 protective orders are waived as provided in section 236A.3.
 18 27    Sec. 33.   17 14    a.  The clerk shall file foreign protective orders that are
 17 15 not certified or authenticated, if supported by an affidavit of
 17 16 a person with personal knowledge, subject to the penalties for
 17 17 perjury. The person protected by the order may provide this
 17 18 affidavit.
 17 19    b.  The clerk shall provide copies of the order as required
 17 20 by section 236A.7, except that notice shall not be provided to
 17 21 the respondent without the express written direction of the
 17 22 person in whose favor the order was entered.
 17 23    3.  a.  A valid foreign protective order has the same effect
 17 24 and shall be enforced in the same manner as a protective order
 17 25 issued in this state whether or not filed with the clerk of the
 17 26 district court or otherwise placed in a registry of protective
 17 27 orders.
 17 28    b.  A foreign protective order is valid if it meets all of
 17 29 the following:
 17 30    (1)  The order states the name of the protected individual
 17 31 and the individual against whom enforcement is sought.
 17 32    (2)  The order has not expired.
 17 33    (3)  The order was issued by a court or tribunal that had
 17 34 jurisdiction over the parties and subject matter under the law
 17 35 of the foreign jurisdiction.
 18  1    (4)  The order was issued in accordance with the respondent's
 18  2 due process rights, either after the respondent was provided
 18  3 with reasonable notice and an opportunity to be heard before
 18  4 the court or tribunal that issued the order, or in the case
 18  5 of an ex parte order, the respondent was granted notice and
 18  6 opportunity to be heard within a reasonable time after the
 18  7 order was issued.
 18  8    c.  Proof that a foreign protective order failed to meet all
 18  9 of the factors listed in paragraph "b" shall be an affirmative
 18 10 defense in any action seeking enforcement of the order.
 18 11    4.  A peace officer shall treat a foreign protective order as
 18 12 a valid legal document and shall make an arrest for a violation
 18 13 of the foreign protective order in the same manner that a peace
 18 14 officer would make an arrest for a violation of a protective
 18 15 order issued within this state.

 17 34 jurisdiction over the parties and subject matter under the law
 17 35 of the foreign jurisdiction.
 18  1    (4)  The order was issued in accordance with the respondent's
 18  2 due process rights, either after the respondent was provided
 18  3 with reasonable notice and an opportunity to be heard before
 18  4 the court or tribunal that issued the order, or in the case
 18  5 of an ex parte order, the respondent was granted notice and
 18  6 opportunity to be heard within a reasonable time after the
 18  7 order was issued.
 18  8    c.  Proof that a foreign protective order failed to meet all
 18  9 of the factors listed in paragraph "b" shall be an affirmative
 18 10 defense in any action seeking enforcement of the order.
 18 11    4.  A peace officer shall treat a foreign protective order as
 18 12 a valid legal document and shall make an arrest for a violation
 18 13 of the foreign protective order in the same manner that a peace
 18 14 officer would make an arrest for a violation of a protective
 18 15 order issued within this state.
 18 16    a.  The fact that a foreign protective order has not been
 18 17 filed with the clerk of the district court or otherwise placed
 18 18 in a registry shall not be grounds to refuse to enforce the
 18 19 terms of the order unless it is apparent to the officer that
 18 20 the order is invalid on its face.
 18 21    b.  A peace officer acting reasonably and in good faith in
 18 22 connection with the enforcement of a foreign protective order
 18 23 shall be immune from civil and criminal liability in any action
 18 24 arising in connection with such enforcement.
 18 25    5.  Filing and service costs in connection with foreign
 18 26 protective orders are waived as provided in section 236A.3.
 18 27    Sec. 33.   17 27 orders.
 17 28    b.  A foreign protective order is valid if it meets all of
 17 29 the following:
 17 30    (1)  The order states the name of the protected individual
 17 31 and the individual against whom enforcement is sought.
 17 32    (2)  The order has not expired.
 17 33    (3)  The order was issued by a court or tribunal that had
 17 34 jurisdiction over the parties and subject matter under the law
 17 35 of the foreign jurisdiction.
 18  1    (4)  The order was issued in accordance with the respondent's
 18  2 due process rights, either after the respondent was provided
 18  3 with reasonable notice and an opportunity to be heard before
 18  4 the court or tribunal that issued the order, or in the case
 18  5 of an ex parte order, the respondent was granted notice and
 18  6 opportunity to be heard within a reasonable time after the
 18  7 order was issued.
 18  8    c.  Proof that a foreign protective order failed to meet all
 18  9 of the factors listed in paragraph "b" shall be an affirmative
 18 10 defense in any action seeking enforcement of the order.
 18 11    4.  A peace officer shall treat a foreign protective order as
 18 12 a valid legal document and shall make an arrest for a violation
 18 13 of the foreign protective order in the same manner that a peace
 18 14 officer would make an arrest for a violation of a protective
 18 15 order issued within this state.

 18 17 filed with the clerk of the district court or otherwise placed

 18 19 terms of the order unless it is apparent to the officer that
 18 20 the order is invalid on its face.

 18 22 connection with the enforcement of a foreign protective order

 18 24 arising in connection with such enforcement.

 18 26 protective orders are waived as provided in section 236A.3.

 18 12 a valid legal document and shall make an arrest for a violation
 18 13 of the foreign protective order in the same manner that a peace
 18 14 officer would make an arrest for a violation of a protective
 18 15 order issued within this state.
 18 16    a.  The fact that a foreign protective order has not been
 18 17 filed with the clerk of the district court or otherwise placed
 18 18 in a registry shall not be grounds to refuse to enforce the
 18 19 terms of the order unless it is apparent to the officer that
 18 20 the order is invalid on its face.
 18 21    b.  A peace officer acting reasonably and in good faith in
 18 22 connection with the enforcement of a foreign protective order
 18 23 shall be immune from civil and criminal liability in any action
 18 24 arising in connection with such enforcement.
 18 25    5.  Filing and service costs in connection with foreign
 18 26 protective orders are waived as provided in section 236A.3.
 18 27    Sec. 33.   18 12 a valid legal document and shall make an arrest for a violation

 18 26 protective orders are waived as provided in section 236A.3.

 18 27    Sec. 33.   18 27    Sec. 33.   18 28 prohibited ==== exceptions.
 18 29    A court in an action under this chapter shall not issue
 18 30 mutual protective orders against the victim and the abuser
 18 31 unless both file a petition requesting a protective order.

 25 10    Sec. 51.  Section 708.2B, unnumbered paragraph 1, Code 2016,
 25 11 is amended to read as follows:
 25 12    As used in this section, "district department" means
 25 13 a judicial district department of correctional services,
 25 14 established pursuant to section 905.2. A person convicted of,
 25 15 or receiving a deferred judgment for, domestic abuse assault as
 25 16 defined in section 708.2A  25  8 in contempt of court for such a violation, as provided in
 25  9 subsection 3.

 25 19 for domestic abuse  25 19 for domestic abuse  25 20 a person convicted of, or receiving a deferred judgment for,
 25 21 an assault, as defined in section 708.1, which is domestic

 25 23 "e",  25 21 an assault, as defined in section 708.1, which is domestic

 25 23 "e",  25 22 abuse, as defined in section 236.2, subsection 2, paragraph
 25 23 "e",  25 23 "e",  25 24 ordered by the court to participate in a batterers' treatment
 25 25 program. Participation in the batterers' treatment program
 25 26 shall not require a person to be placed on probation, but
 25 27 a person on probation may participate in the program. The
 25 28 district departments may contract for services in completing
 25 29 the duties relating to the batterers' treatment programs. The
 25 30 district departments shall assess the fees for participation
 25 31 in the program, and shall either collect or contract for the
 25 32 collection of the fees to recoup the costs of treatment,
 25 33 but may waive the fee or collect a lesser amount upon a
 25 34 showing of cause. The fees shall be used by each of the
 25 35 district departments or contract service providers for the
 26  1 establishment, administration, coordination, and provision of
 26  2 direct services of the batterers' treatment programs.

 25 32 collection of the fees to recoup the costs of treatment,

 25 34 showing of cause. The fees shall be used by each of the
 25 35 district departments or contract service providers for the
 26  1 establishment, administration, coordination, and provision of
 26  2 direct services of the batterers' treatment programs.

 25 35 district departments or contract service providers for the
 26  1 establishment, administration, coordination, and provision of
 26  2 direct services of the batterers' treatment programs.
 26  3    Sec. 52.   25 35 district departments or contract service providers for the
 26  1 establishment, administration, coordination, and provision of
 26  2 direct services of the batterers' treatment programs.
 26  3    Sec. 52.   26  1 establishment, administration, coordination, and provision of
 26  2 direct services of the batterers' treatment programs.
 26  3    Sec. 52.   26  2 direct services of the batterers' treatment programs.
 26  3    Sec. 52.   26  3    Sec. 52.   26  4 mandatory minimums, penalties enhanced == extension of no=contact
 26  5 order.
 26  6    1.  For the purposes of this chapter, "dating abuse assault"
 26  7 means an assault, as defined in section 708.1, which is dating
 26  8 abuse, as defined in section 236A.2.
 26  9    2.  On a first offense of dating abuse assault, the person
 26 10 commits:
 26 11    a.  A simple misdemeanor for a dating abuse assault, except
 26 12 as otherwise provided.
 26 13    b.  A serious misdemeanor, if the dating abuse assault causes
 26 14 bodily injury or mental illness.
 26 15    c.  An aggravated misdemeanor, if the dating abuse assault
 26 16 is committed with the intent to inflict a serious injury upon
 26 17 another, or if the person uses or displays a dangerous weapon
 26 18 in connection with the assault. This paragraph does not apply
 26 19 if section 708.6 or 708.8 applies.
 26 20    d.  An aggravated misdemeanor, if the dating abuse assault
 26 21 is committed by knowingly impeding the normal breathing or
 26 22 circulation of the blood of another by applying pressure to the
 26 23 throat or neck of the other person or by obstructing the nose
 26 24 or mouth of the other person.
 26 25    3.  Except as otherwise provided in subsection 2, on a second
 26 26 dating abuse assault, a person commits:
 26 27    a.  A serious misdemeanor, if the first offense was
 26 28 classified as a simple misdemeanor, and the second offense
 26 29 would otherwise be classified as a simple misdemeanor.
 26 30    b.  An aggravated misdemeanor, if the first offense was
 26 31 classified as a simple or aggravated misdemeanor, and the
 26 32 second offense would otherwise be classified as a serious
 26 33 misdemeanor, or the first offense was classified as a serious
 26 34 or aggravated misdemeanor, and the second offense would
 26 35 otherwise be classified as a simple or serious misdemeanor.
 27  1    4.  On a third or subsequent offense of dating abuse assault,
 27  2 a person commits a class "D" felony.
 27  3    5.  For a dating abuse assault committed by knowingly
 27  4 impeding the normal breathing or circulation of the blood of
 27  5 another by applying pressure to the throat or neck of the other
 27  6 person or by obstructing the nose or mouth of the other person,
 27  7 and causing bodily injury, the person commits a class "D"
 27  8 felony.
 27  9    6.  a.  A conviction for, deferred judgment for, or plea of
 27 10 guilty to, a violation of this section which occurred more than
 27 11 twelve years prior to the date of the violation charged shall
 27 12 not be considered in determining that the violation charged is
 27 13 a second or subsequent offense.
 27 14    b.  For the purpose of determining if a violation charged
 27 15 is a second or subsequent offense, deferred judgments issued
 27 16 pursuant to section 907.3 for violations of section 708.2 or
 27 17 this section, which were issued on dating abuse assaults,
 27 18 and convictions or the equivalent of deferred judgments for
 27 19 violations in any other states under statutes substantially
 27 20 corresponding to this section shall be counted as previous
 27 21 offenses. The courts shall judicially notice the statutes of
 27 22 other states which define offenses substantially equivalent
 27 23 to the offenses defined in this section and can therefore be
 27 24 considered corresponding statutes. Each previous violation on
 27 25 which conviction or deferral of judgment was entered prior to
 27 26 the date of the offense charged shall be considered and counted
 27 27 as a separate previous offense.
 27 28    c.  An offense shall be considered a prior offense regardless
 27 29 of whether it was committed upon the same victim.
 27 30    7.  a.  A person convicted of violating subsection 2 or 3
 27 31 shall serve a minimum term of two days of the sentence imposed
 27 32 by law, and shall not be eligible for suspension of the minimum
 27 33 sentence. The minimum term shall be served on consecutive
 27 34 days. The court shall not impose a fine in lieu of the minimum
 27 35 sentence, although a fine may be imposed in addition to the
 28  1 minimum sentence. This section does not prohibit the court
 28  2 from sentencing and the person from serving the maximum term of
 28  3 confinement or from paying the maximum fine permitted pursuant
 28  4 to chapter 902 or 903, and does not prohibit the court from
 28  5 entering a deferred judgment or sentence pursuant to section
 28  6 907.3, if the person has not previously received a deferred
 28  7 sentence or judgment for a violation of section 708.2 or this
 28  8 section which was issued on a dating abuse assault.
 28  9    b.  A person convicted of violating subsection 4 shall
 28 10 be sentenced as provided under section 902.9, subsection 1,
 28 11 paragraph "e", and shall be denied parole or work release until
 28 12 the person has served a minimum of one year of the person's
 28 13 sentence. Notwithstanding section 901.5, subsections 1, 3, and
 28 14 5, and section 907.3, the person cannot receive a suspended or
 28 15 deferred sentence or a deferred judgment; however, the person
 28 16 sentenced shall receive credit for any time the person was
 28 17 confined in a jail or detention facility following arrest.
 28 18    8.  If a person is convicted for, receives a deferred
 28 19 judgment for, or pleads guilty to a violation of this section,
 28 20 the court shall modify the no=contact order issued upon initial
 28 21 appearance in the manner provided in section 664A.5, regardless
 28 22 of whether the person is placed on probation.
 28 23    9.  The clerk of the district court shall provide notice
 28 24 and copies of a judgment entered under this section to the
 28 25 applicable law enforcement agencies and the twenty=four=hour
 28 26 dispatcher for the law enforcement agencies, in the manner
 28 27 provided for protective orders under section 236A.7. The
 28 28 clerk shall provide notice and copies of modifications of the
 28 29 judgment in the same manner.
 28 30    10.  In addition to the mandatory minimum term of confinement
 28 31 imposed by subsection 7, paragraph "a", the court shall order
 28 32 a person convicted under subsection 2 or 3 to participate
 28 33 in a batterers' treatment program as required under section
 28 34 708.2B.  In addition, as a condition of deferring judgment or
 28 35 sentence pursuant to section 907.3, the court shall order the
 29  1 person to participate in a batterers' treatment program. The
 29  2 clerk of the district court shall send a copy of the judgment
 29  3 or deferred judgment to the judicial district department of
 29  4 correctional services.
 29  5    Sec. 53.  Section 804.7, subsection 5, Code 2016, is amended
 29  6 to read as follows:

 29  6 to read as follows:

 29  8 that domestic abuse, as defined in section 236.2,  26  7 means an assault, as defined in section 708.1, which is dating
 26  8 abuse, as defined in section 236A.2.

 26 10 commits:

 26 12 as otherwise provided.

 26 14 bodily injury or mental illness.

 26 33 misdemeanor, or the first offense was classified as a serious
 26 34 or aggravated misdemeanor, and the second offense would
 26 35 otherwise be classified as a simple or serious misdemeanor.
 27  1    4.  On a third or subsequent offense of dating abuse assault,
 27  2 a person commits a class "D" felony.
 27  3    5.  For a dating abuse assault committed by knowingly
 27  4 impeding the normal breathing or circulation of the blood of
 27  5 another by applying pressure to the throat or neck of the other
 27  6 person or by obstructing the nose or mouth of the other person,
 27  7 and causing bodily injury, the person commits a class "D"
 27  8 felony.
 27  9    6.  a.  A conviction for, deferred judgment for, or plea of
 27 10 guilty to, a violation of this section which occurred more than
 27 11 twelve years prior to the date of the violation charged shall
 27 12 not be considered in determining that the violation charged is
 27 13 a second or subsequent offense.
 27 14    b.  For the purpose of determining if a violation charged
 27 15 is a second or subsequent offense, deferred judgments issued
 27 16 pursuant to section 907.3 for violations of section 708.2 or
 27 17 this section, which were issued on dating abuse assaults,
 27 18 and convictions or the equivalent of deferred judgments for
 27 19 violations in any other states under statutes substantially
 27 20 corresponding to this section shall be counted as previous
 27 21 offenses. The courts shall judicially notice the statutes of
 27 22 other states which define offenses substantially equivalent
 27 23 to the offenses defined in this section and can therefore be
 27 24 considered corresponding statutes. Each previous violation on
 27 25 which conviction or deferral of judgment was entered prior to
 27 26 the date of the offense charged shall be considered and counted
 27 27 as a separate previous offense.
 27 28    c.  An offense shall be considered a prior offense regardless
 27 29 of whether it was committed upon the same victim.
 27 30    7.  a.  A person convicted of violating subsection 2 or 3
 27 31 shall serve a minimum term of two days of the sentence imposed
 27 32 by law, and shall not be eligible for suspension of the minimum
 27 33 sentence. The minimum term shall be served on consecutive
 27 34 days. The court shall not impose a fine in lieu of the minimum
 27 35 sentence, although a fine may be imposed in addition to the
 28  1 minimum sentence. This section does not prohibit the court
 28  2 from sentencing and the person from serving the maximum term of
 28  3 confinement or from paying the maximum fine permitted pursuant
 28  4 to chapter 902 or 903, and does not prohibit the court from
 28  5 entering a deferred judgment or sentence pursuant to section
 28  6 907.3, if the person has not previously received a deferred
 28  7 sentence or judgment for a violation of section 708.2 or this
 28  8 section which was issued on a dating abuse assault.
 28  9    b.  A person convicted of violating subsection 4 shall
 28 10 be sentenced as provided under section 902.9, subsection 1,
 28 11 paragraph "e", and shall be denied parole or work release until
 28 12 the person has served a minimum of one year of the person's
 28 13 sentence. Notwithstanding section 901.5, subsections 1, 3, and
 28 14 5, and section 907.3, the person cannot receive a suspended or
 28 15 deferred sentence or a deferred judgment; however, the person
 28 16 sentenced shall receive credit for any time the person was
 28 17 confined in a jail or detention facility following arrest.
 28 18    8.  If a person is convicted for, receives a deferred
 28 19 judgment for, or pleads guilty to a violation of this section,
 28 20 the court shall modify the no=contact order issued upon initial
 28 21 appearance in the manner provided in section 664A.5, regardless
 28 22 of whether the person is placed on probation.
 28 23    9.  The clerk of the district court shall provide notice
 28 24 and copies of a judgment entered under this section to the
 28 25 applicable law enforcement agencies and the twenty=four=hour
 28 26 dispatcher for the law enforcement agencies, in the manner
 28 27 provided for protective orders under section 236A.7. The
 28 28 clerk shall provide notice and copies of modifications of the
 28 29 judgment in the same manner.
 28 30    10.  In addition to the mandatory minimum term of confinement
 28 31 imposed by subsection 7, paragraph "a", the court shall order
 28 32 a person convicted under subsection 2 or 3 to participate
 28 33 in a batterers' treatment program as required under section
 28 34 708.2B.  In addition, as a condition of deferring judgment or
 28 35 sentence pursuant to section 907.3, the court shall order the
 29  1 person to participate in a batterers' treatment program. The
 29  2 clerk of the district court shall send a copy of the judgment
 29  3 or deferred judgment to the judicial district department of
 29  4 correctional services.
 29  5    Sec. 53.  Section 804.7, subsection 5, Code 2016, is amended
 29  6 to read as follows:
 29  7    5.  If the peace officer has reasonable grounds for believing
 29  8 that domestic abuse, as defined in section 236.2,  26  8 abuse, as defined in section 236A.2.
 26  9    2.  On a first offense of dating abuse assault, the person
 26 10 commits:
 26 11    a.  A simple misdemeanor for a dating abuse assault, except
 26 12 as otherwise provided.
 26 13    b.  A serious misdemeanor, if the dating abuse assault causes
 26 14 bodily injury or mental illness.
 26 15    c.  An aggravated misdemeanor, if the dating abuse assault
 26 16 is committed with the intent to inflict a serious injury upon
 26 17 another, or if the person uses or displays a dangerous weapon
 26 18 in connection with the assault. This paragraph does not apply
 26 19 if section 708.6 or 708.8 applies.
 26 20    d.  An aggravated misdemeanor, if the dating abuse assault
 26 21 is committed by knowingly impeding the normal breathing or
 26 22 circulation of the blood of another by applying pressure to the
 26 23 throat or neck of the other person or by obstructing the nose
 26 24 or mouth of the other person.
 26 25    3.  Except as otherwise provided in subsection 2, on a second
 26 26 dating abuse assault, a person commits:
 26 27    a.  A serious misdemeanor, if the first offense was
 26 28 classified as a simple misdemeanor, and the second offense
 26 29 would otherwise be classified as a simple misdemeanor.
 26 30    b.  An aggravated misdemeanor, if the first offense was
 26 31 classified as a simple or aggravated misdemeanor, and the
 26 32 second offense would otherwise be classified as a serious
 26 33 misdemeanor, or the first offense was classified as a serious
 26 34 or aggravated misdemeanor, and the second offense would
 26 35 otherwise be classified as a simple or serious misdemeanor.
 27  1    4.  On a third or subsequent offense of dating abuse assault,
 27  2 a person commits a class "D" felony.
 27  3    5.  For a dating abuse assault committed by knowingly
 27  4 impeding the normal breathing or circulation of the blood of
 27  5 another by applying pressure to the throat or neck of the other
 27  6 person or by obstructing the nose or mouth of the other person,
 27  7 and causing bodily injury, the person commits a class "D"
 27  8 felony.
 27  9    6.  a.  A conviction for, deferred judgment for, or plea of
 27 10 guilty to, a violation of this section which occurred more than
 27 11 twelve years prior to the date of the violation charged shall
 27 12 not be considered in determining that the violation charged is
 27 13 a second or subsequent offense.
 27 14    b.  For the purpose of determining if a violation charged
 27 15 is a second or subsequent offense, deferred judgments issued
 27 16 pursuant to section 907.3 for violations of section 708.2 or
 27 17 this section, which were issued on dating abuse assaults,
 27 18 and convictions or the equivalent of deferred judgments for
 27 19 violations in any other states under statutes substantially
 27 20 corresponding to this section shall be counted as previous
 27 21 offenses. The courts shall judicially notice the statutes of
 27 22 other states which define offenses substantially equivalent
 27 23 to the offenses defined in this section and can therefore be
 27 24 considered corresponding statutes. Each previous violation on
 27 25 which conviction or deferral of judgment was entered prior to
 27 26 the date of the offense charged shall be considered and counted
 27 27 as a separate previous offense.
 27 28    c.  An offense shall be considered a prior offense regardless
 27 29 of whether it was committed upon the same victim.
 27 30    7.  a.  A person convicted of violating subsection 2 or 3
 27 31 shall serve a minimum term of two days of the sentence imposed
 27 32 by law, and shall not be eligible for suspension of the minimum
 27 33 sentence. The minimum term shall be served on consecutive
 27 34 days. The court shall not impose a fine in lieu of the minimum
 27 35 sentence, although a fine may be imposed in addition to the
 28  1 minimum sentence. This section does not prohibit the court
 28  2 from sentencing and the person from serving the maximum term of
 28  3 confinement or from paying the maximum fine permitted pursuant
 28  4 to chapter 902 or 903, and does not prohibit the court from
 28  5 entering a deferred judgment or sentence pursuant to section
 28  6 907.3, if the person has not previously received a deferred
 28  7 sentence or judgment for a violation of section 708.2 or this
 28  8 section which was issued on a dating abuse assault.
 28  9    b.  A person convicted of violating subsection 4 shall
 28 10 be sentenced as provided under section 902.9, subsection 1,
 28 11 paragraph "e", and shall be denied parole or work release until
 28 12 the person has served a minimum of one year of the person's
 28 13 sentence. Notwithstanding section 901.5, subsections 1, 3, and
 28 14 5, and section 907.3, the person cannot receive a suspended or
 28 15 deferred sentence or a deferred judgment; however, the person
 28 16 sentenced shall receive credit for any time the person was
 28 17 confined in a jail or detention facility following arrest.
 28 18    8.  If a person is convicted for, receives a deferred
 28 19 judgment for, or pleads guilty to a violation of this section,
 28 20 the court shall modify the no=contact order issued upon initial
 28 21 appearance in the manner provided in section 664A.5, regardless
 28 22 of whether the person is placed on probation.
 28 23    9.  The clerk of the district court shall provide notice
 28 24 and copies of a judgment entered under this section to the
 28 25 applicable law enforcement agencies and the twenty=four=hour
 28 26 dispatcher for the law enforcement agencies, in the manner
 28 27 provided for protective orders under section 236A.7. The
 28 28 clerk shall provide notice and copies of modifications of the
 28 29 judgment in the same manner.
 28 30    10.  In addition to the mandatory minimum term of confinement
 28 31 imposed by subsection 7, paragraph "a", the court shall order
 28 32 a person convicted under subsection 2 or 3 to participate
 28 33 in a batterers' treatment program as required under section
 28 34 708.2B.  In addition, as a condition of deferring judgment or
 28 35 sentence pursuant to section 907.3, the court shall order the
 29  1 person to participate in a batterers' treatment program. The
 29  2 clerk of the district court shall send a copy of the judgment
 29  3 or deferred judgment to the judicial district department of
 29  4 correctional services.
 29  5    Sec. 53.  Section 804.7, subsection 5, Code 2016, is amended
 29  6 to read as follows:
 29  7    5.  If the peace officer has reasonable grounds for believing
 29  8 that domestic abuse, as defined in section 236.2,  26  9    2.  On a first offense of dating abuse assault, the person

 26 21 is committed by knowingly impeding the normal breathing or

 26 28 classified as a simple misdemeanor, and the second offense
 26 29 would otherwise be classified as a simple misdemeanor.

 26 32 second offense would otherwise be classified as a serious

 28  7 sentence or judgment for a violation of section 708.2 or this
 28  8 section which was issued on a dating abuse assault.
 28  9    b.  A person convicted of violating subsection 4 shall
 28 10 be sentenced as provided under section 902.9, subsection 1,
 28 11 paragraph "e", and shall be denied parole or work release until
 28 12 the person has served a minimum of one year of the person's
 28 13 sentence. Notwithstanding section 901.5, subsections 1, 3, and
 28 14 5, and section 907.3, the person cannot receive a suspended or
 28 15 deferred sentence or a deferred judgment; however, the person
 28 16 sentenced shall receive credit for any time the person was
 28 17 confined in a jail or detention facility following arrest.

 28 19 judgment for, or pleads guilty to a violation of this section,
 28 20 the court shall modify the no=contact order issued upon initial
 28 21 appearance in the manner provided in section 664A.5, regardless
 28 22 of whether the person is placed on probation.

 28 24 and copies of a judgment entered under this section to the
 28 25 applicable law enforcement agencies and the twenty=four=hour
 28 26 dispatcher for the law enforcement agencies, in the manner
 28 27 provided for protective orders under section 236A.7. The
 28 28 clerk shall provide notice and copies of modifications of the
 28 29 judgment in the same manner.
 28 30    10.  In addition to the mandatory minimum term of confinement
 28 31 imposed by subsection 7, paragraph "a", the court shall order
 28 32 a person convicted under subsection 2 or 3 to participate
 28 33 in a batterers' treatment program as required under section
 28 34 708.2B.  In addition, as a condition of deferring judgment or
 28 35 sentence pursuant to section 907.3, the court shall order the
 29  1 person to participate in a batterers' treatment program. The
 29  2 clerk of the district court shall send a copy of the judgment
 29  3 or deferred judgment to the judicial district department of
 29  4 correctional services.

 27  2 a person commits a class "D" felony.
 27  3    5.  For a dating abuse assault committed by knowingly
 27  4 impeding the normal breathing or circulation of the blood of
 27  5 another by applying pressure to the throat or neck of the other
 27  6 person or by obstructing the nose or mouth of the other person,
 27  7 and causing bodily injury, the person commits a class "D"
 27  8 felony.
 27  9    6.  a.  A conviction for, deferred judgment for, or plea of
 27 10 guilty to, a violation of this section which occurred more than
 27 11 twelve years prior to the date of the violation charged shall
 27 12 not be considered in determining that the violation charged is
 27 13 a second or subsequent offense.
 27 14    b.  For the purpose of determining if a violation charged
 27 15 is a second or subsequent offense, deferred judgments issued
 27 16 pursuant to section 907.3 for violations of section 708.2 or
 27 17 this section, which were issued on dating abuse assaults,
 27 18 and convictions or the equivalent of deferred judgments for
 27 19 violations in any other states under statutes substantially
 27 20 corresponding to this section shall be counted as previous
 27 21 offenses. The courts shall judicially notice the statutes of
 27 22 other states which define offenses substantially equivalent
 27 23 to the offenses defined in this section and can therefore be
 27 24 considered corresponding statutes. Each previous violation on
 27 25 which conviction or deferral of judgment was entered prior to
 27 26 the date of the offense charged shall be considered and counted
 27 27 as a separate previous offense.
 27 28    c.  An offense shall be considered a prior offense regardless
 27 29 of whether it was committed upon the same victim.
 27 30    7.  a.  A person convicted of violating subsection 2 or 3
 27 31 shall serve a minimum term of two days of the sentence imposed
 27 32 by law, and shall not be eligible for suspension of the minimum
 27 33 sentence. The minimum term shall be served on consecutive
 27 34 days. The court shall not impose a fine in lieu of the minimum
 27 35 sentence, although a fine may be imposed in addition to the
 28  1 minimum sentence. This section does not prohibit the court
 28  2 from sentencing and the person from serving the maximum term of
 28  3 confinement or from paying the maximum fine permitted pursuant
 28  4 to chapter 902 or 903, and does not prohibit the court from
 28  5 entering a deferred judgment or sentence pursuant to section
 28  6 907.3, if the person has not previously received a deferred
 28  7 sentence or judgment for a violation of section 708.2 or this
 28  8 section which was issued on a dating abuse assault.
 28  9    b.  A person convicted of violating subsection 4 shall
 28 10 be sentenced as provided under section 902.9, subsection 1,
 28 11 paragraph "e", and shall be denied parole or work release until
 28 12 the person has served a minimum of one year of the person's
 28 13 sentence. Notwithstanding section 901.5, subsections 1, 3, and
 28 14 5, and section 907.3, the person cannot receive a suspended or
 28 15 deferred sentence or a deferred judgment; however, the person
 28 16 sentenced shall receive credit for any time the person was
 28 17 confined in a jail or detention facility following arrest.
 28 18    8.  If a person is convicted for, receives a deferred
 28 19 judgment for, or pleads guilty to a violation of this section,
 28 20 the court shall modify the no=contact order issued upon initial
 28 21 appearance in the manner provided in section 664A.5, regardless
 28 22 of whether the person is placed on probation.
 28 23    9.  The clerk of the district court shall provide notice
 28 24 and copies of a judgment entered under this section to the
 28 25 applicable law enforcement agencies and the twenty=four=hour
 28 26 dispatcher for the law enforcement agencies, in the manner
 28 27 provided for protective orders under section 236A.7. The
 28 28 clerk shall provide notice and copies of modifications of the
 28 29 judgment in the same manner.
 28 30    10.  In addition to the mandatory minimum term of confinement
 28 31 imposed by subsection 7, paragraph "a", the court shall order
 28 32 a person convicted under subsection 2 or 3 to participate
 28 33 in a batterers' treatment program as required under section
 28 34 708.2B.  In addition, as a condition of deferring judgment or
 28 35 sentence pursuant to section 907.3, the court shall order the
 29  1 person to participate in a batterers' treatment program. The
 29  2 clerk of the district court shall send a copy of the judgment
 29  3 or deferred judgment to the judicial district department of
 29  4 correctional services.
 29  5    Sec. 53.  Section 804.7, subsection 5, Code 2016, is amended
 29  6 to read as follows:
 29  7    5.  If the peace officer has reasonable grounds for believing
 29  8 that domestic abuse, as defined in section 236.2,  26 13    b.  A serious misdemeanor, if the dating abuse assault causes
 26 14 bodily injury or mental illness.
 26 15    c.  An aggravated misdemeanor, if the dating abuse assault
 26 16 is committed with the intent to inflict a serious injury upon
 26 17 another, or if the person uses or displays a dangerous weapon
 26 18 in connection with the assault. This paragraph does not apply
 26 19 if section 708.6 or 708.8 applies.
 26 20    d.  An aggravated misdemeanor, if the dating abuse assault
 26 21 is committed by knowingly impeding the normal breathing or
 26 22 circulation of the blood of another by applying pressure to the
 26 23 throat or neck of the other person or by obstructing the nose
 26 24 or mouth of the other person.
 26 25    3.  Except as otherwise provided in subsection 2, on a second
 26 26 dating abuse assault, a person commits:
 26 27    a.  A serious misdemeanor, if the first offense was
 26 28 classified as a simple misdemeanor, and the second offense
 26 29 would otherwise be classified as a simple misdemeanor.
 26 30    b.  An aggravated misdemeanor, if the first offense was
 26 31 classified as a simple or aggravated misdemeanor, and the
 26 32 second offense would otherwise be classified as a serious
 26 33 misdemeanor, or the first offense was classified as a serious
 26 34 or aggravated misdemeanor, and the second offense would
 26 35 otherwise be classified as a simple or serious misdemeanor.
 27  1    4.  On a third or subsequent offense of dating abuse assault,
 27  2 a person commits a class "D" felony.
 27  3    5.  For a dating abuse assault committed by knowingly
 27  4 impeding the normal breathing or circulation of the blood of
 27  5 another by applying pressure to the throat or neck of the other
 27  6 person or by obstructing the nose or mouth of the other person,
 27  7 and causing bodily injury, the person commits a class "D"
 27  8 felony.
 27  9    6.  a.  A conviction for, deferred judgment for, or plea of
 27 10 guilty to, a violation of this section which occurred more than
 27 11 twelve years prior to the date of the violation charged shall
 27 12 not be considered in determining that the violation charged is
 27 13 a second or subsequent offense.
 27 14    b.  For the purpose of determining if a violation charged
 27 15 is a second or subsequent offense, deferred judgments issued
 27 16 pursuant to section 907.3 for violations of section 708.2 or
 27 17 this section, which were issued on dating abuse assaults,
 27 18 and convictions or the equivalent of deferred judgments for
 27 19 violations in any other states under statutes substantially
 27 20 corresponding to this section shall be counted as previous
 27 21 offenses. The courts shall judicially notice the statutes of
 27 22 other states which define offenses substantially equivalent
 27 23 to the offenses defined in this section and can therefore be
 27 24 considered corresponding statutes. Each previous violation on
 27 25 which conviction or deferral of judgment was entered prior to
 27 26 the date of the offense charged shall be considered and counted
 27 27 as a separate previous offense.
 27 28    c.  An offense shall be considered a prior offense regardless
 27 29 of whether it was committed upon the same victim.
 27 30    7.  a.  A person convicted of violating subsection 2 or 3
 27 31 shall serve a minimum term of two days of the sentence imposed
 27 32 by law, and shall not be eligible for suspension of the minimum
 27 33 sentence. The minimum term shall be served on consecutive
 27 34 days. The court shall not impose a fine in lieu of the minimum
 27 35 sentence, although a fine may be imposed in addition to the
 28  1 minimum sentence. This section does not prohibit the court
 28  2 from sentencing and the person from serving the maximum term of
 28  3 confinement or from paying the maximum fine permitted pursuant
 28  4 to chapter 902 or 903, and does not prohibit the court from
 28  5 entering a deferred judgment or sentence pursuant to section
 28  6 907.3, if the person has not previously received a deferred
 28  7 sentence or judgment for a violation of section 708.2 or this
 28  8 section which was issued on a dating abuse assault.
 28  9    b.  A person convicted of violating subsection 4 shall
 28 10 be sentenced as provided under section 902.9, subsection 1,
 28 11 paragraph "e", and shall be denied parole or work release until
 28 12 the person has served a minimum of one year of the person's
 28 13 sentence. Notwithstanding section 901.5, subsections 1, 3, and
 28 14 5, and section 907.3, the person cannot receive a suspended or
 28 15 deferred sentence or a deferred judgment; however, the person
 28 16 sentenced shall receive credit for any time the person was
 28 17 confined in a jail or detention facility following arrest.
 28 18    8.  If a person is convicted for, receives a deferred
 28 19 judgment for, or pleads guilty to a violation of this section,
 28 20 the court shall modify the no=contact order issued upon initial
 28 21 appearance in the manner provided in section 664A.5, regardless
 28 22 of whether the person is placed on probation.
 28 23    9.  The clerk of the district court shall provide notice
 28 24 and copies of a judgment entered under this section to the
 28 25 applicable law enforcement agencies and the twenty=four=hour
 28 26 dispatcher for the law enforcement agencies, in the manner
 28 27 provided for protective orders under section 236A.7. The
 28 28 clerk shall provide notice and copies of modifications of the
 28 29 judgment in the same manner.
 28 30    10.  In addition to the mandatory minimum term of confinement
 28 31 imposed by subsection 7, paragraph "a", the court shall order
 28 32 a person convicted under subsection 2 or 3 to participate
 28 33 in a batterers' treatment program as required under section
 28 34 708.2B.  In addition, as a condition of deferring judgment or
 28 35 sentence pursuant to section 907.3, the court shall order the
 29  1 person to participate in a batterers' treatment program. The
 29  2 clerk of the district court shall send a copy of the judgment
 29  3 or deferred judgment to the judicial district department of
 29  4 correctional services.

 27 29 of whether it was committed upon the same victim.
 27 30    7.  a.  A person convicted of violating subsection 2 or 3
 27 31 shall serve a minimum term of two days of the sentence imposed
 27 32 by law, and shall not be eligible for suspension of the minimum
 27 33 sentence. The minimum term shall be served on consecutive
 27 34 days. The court shall not impose a fine in lieu of the minimum
 27 35 sentence, although a fine may be imposed in addition to the
 28  1 minimum sentence. This section does not prohibit the court
 28  2 from sentencing and the person from serving the maximum term of
 28  3 confinement or from paying the maximum fine permitted pursuant
 28  4 to chapter 902 or 903, and does not prohibit the court from
 28  5 entering a deferred judgment or sentence pursuant to section
 28  6 907.3, if the person has not previously received a deferred
 28  7 sentence or judgment for a violation of section 708.2 or this
 28  8 section which was issued on a dating abuse assault.
 28  9    b.  A person convicted of violating subsection 4 shall
 28 10 be sentenced as provided under section 902.9, subsection 1,
 28 11 paragraph "e", and shall be denied parole or work release until
 28 12 the person has served a minimum of one year of the person's
 28 13 sentence. Notwithstanding section 901.5, subsections 1, 3, and
 28 14 5, and section 907.3, the person cannot receive a suspended or
 28 15 deferred sentence or a deferred judgment; however, the person
 28 16 sentenced shall receive credit for any time the person was
 28 17 confined in a jail or detention facility following arrest.
 28 18    8.  If a person is convicted for, receives a deferred
 28 19 judgment for, or pleads guilty to a violation of this section,
 28 20 the court shall modify the no=contact order issued upon initial
 28 21 appearance in the manner provided in section 664A.5, regardless
 28 22 of whether the person is placed on probation.
 28 23    9.  The clerk of the district court shall provide notice
 28 24 and copies of a judgment entered under this section to the
 28 25 applicable law enforcement agencies and the twenty=four=hour
 28 26 dispatcher for the law enforcement agencies, in the manner
 28 27 provided for protective orders under section 236A.7. The
 28 28 clerk shall provide notice and copies of modifications of the
 28 29 judgment in the same manner.
 28 30    10.  In addition to the mandatory minimum term of confinement
 28 31 imposed by subsection 7, paragraph "a", the court shall order
 28 32 a person convicted under subsection 2 or 3 to participate
 28 33 in a batterers' treatment program as required under section
 28 34 708.2B.  In addition, as a condition of deferring judgment or
 28 35 sentence pursuant to section 907.3, the court shall order the
 29  1 person to participate in a batterers' treatment program. The
 29  2 clerk of the district court shall send a copy of the judgment
 29  3 or deferred judgment to the judicial district department of
 29  4 correctional services.
 29  5    Sec. 53.  Section 804.7, subsection 5, Code 2016, is amended
 29  6 to read as follows:
 29  7    5.  If the peace officer has reasonable grounds for believing
 29  8 that domestic abuse, as defined in section 236.2,  26 18 in connection with the assault. This paragraph does not apply
 26 19 if section 708.6 or 708.8 applies.
 26 20    d.  An aggravated misdemeanor, if the dating abuse assault
 26 21 is committed by knowingly impeding the normal breathing or
 26 22 circulation of the blood of another by applying pressure to the
 26 23 throat or neck of the other person or by obstructing the nose
 26 24 or mouth of the other person.
 26 25    3.  Except as otherwise provided in subsection 2, on a second
 26 26 dating abuse assault, a person commits:
 26 27    a.  A serious misdemeanor, if the first offense was
 26 28 classified as a simple misdemeanor, and the second offense
 26 29 would otherwise be classified as a simple misdemeanor.
 26 30    b.  An aggravated misdemeanor, if the first offense was
 26 31 classified as a simple or aggravated misdemeanor, and the
 26 32 second offense would otherwise be classified as a serious
 26 33 misdemeanor, or the first offense was classified as a serious
 26 34 or aggravated misdemeanor, and the second offense would
 26 35 otherwise be classified as a simple or serious misdemeanor.
 27  1    4.  On a third or subsequent offense of dating abuse assault,
 27  2 a person commits a class "D" felony.
 27  3    5.  For a dating abuse assault committed by knowingly
 27  4 impeding the normal breathing or circulation of the blood of
 27  5 another by applying pressure to the throat or neck of the other
 27  6 person or by obstructing the nose or mouth of the other person,
 27  7 and causing bodily injury, the person commits a class "D"
 27  8 felony.
 27  9    6.  a.  A conviction for, deferred judgment for, or plea of
 27 10 guilty to, a violation of this section which occurred more than
 27 11 twelve years prior to the date of the violation charged shall
 27 12 not be considered in determining that the violation charged is
 27 13 a second or subsequent offense.
 27 14    b.  For the purpose of determining if a violation charged
 27 15 is a second or subsequent offense, deferred judgments issued
 27 16 pursuant to section 907.3 for violations of section 708.2 or
 27 17 this section, which were issued on dating abuse assaults,
 27 18 and convictions or the equivalent of deferred judgments for
 27 19 violations in any other states under statutes substantially
 27 20 corresponding to this section shall be counted as previous
 27 21 offenses. The courts shall judicially notice the statutes of
 27 22 other states which define offenses substantially equivalent
 27 23 to the offenses defined in this section and can therefore be
 27 24 considered corresponding statutes. Each previous violation on
 27 25 which conviction or deferral of judgment was entered prior to
 27 26 the date of the offense charged shall be considered and counted
 27 27 as a separate previous offense.
 27 28    c.  An offense shall be considered a prior offense regardless
 27 29 of whether it was committed upon the same victim.
 27 30    7.  a.  A person convicted of violating subsection 2 or 3
 27 31 shall serve a minimum term of two days of the sentence imposed
 27 32 by law, and shall not be eligible for suspension of the minimum
 27 33 sentence. The minimum term shall be served on consecutive
 27 34 days. The court shall not impose a fine in lieu of the minimum
 27 35 sentence, although a fine may be imposed in addition to the
 28  1 minimum sentence. This section does not prohibit the court
 28  2 from sentencing and the person from serving the maximum term of
 28  3 confinement or from paying the maximum fine permitted pursuant
 28  4 to chapter 902 or 903, and does not prohibit the court from
 28  5 entering a deferred judgment or sentence pursuant to section
 28  6 907.3, if the person has not previously received a deferred
 28  7 sentence or judgment for a violation of section 708.2 or this
 28  8 section which was issued on a dating abuse assault.
 28  9    b.  A person convicted of violating subsection 4 shall
 28 10 be sentenced as provided under section 902.9, subsection 1,
 28 11 paragraph "e", and shall be denied parole or work release until
 28 12 the person has served a minimum of one year of the person's
 28 13 sentence. Notwithstanding section 901.5, subsections 1, 3, and
 28 14 5, and section 907.3, the person cannot receive a suspended or
 28 15 deferred sentence or a deferred judgment; however, the person
 28 16 sentenced shall receive credit for any time the person was
 28 17 confined in a jail or detention facility following arrest.
 28 18    8.  If a person is convicted for, receives a deferred
 28 19 judgment for, or pleads guilty to a violation of this section,
 28 20 the court shall modify the no=contact order issued upon initial
 28 21 appearance in the manner provided in section 664A.5, regardless
 28 22 of whether the person is placed on probation.
 28 23    9.  The clerk of the district court shall provide notice
 28 24 and copies of a judgment entered under this section to the
 28 25 applicable law enforcement agencies and the twenty=four=hour
 28 26 dispatcher for the law enforcement agencies, in the manner
 28 27 provided for protective orders under section 236A.7. The
 28 28 clerk shall provide notice and copies of modifications of the
 28 29 judgment in the same manner.
 28 30    10.  In addition to the mandatory minimum term of confinement
 28 31 imposed by subsection 7, paragraph "a", the court shall order
 28 32 a person convicted under subsection 2 or 3 to participate
 28 33 in a batterers' treatment program as required under section
 28 34 708.2B.  In addition, as a condition of deferring judgment or
 28 35 sentence pursuant to section 907.3, the court shall order the
 29  1 person to participate in a batterers' treatment program. The
 29  2 clerk of the district court shall send a copy of the judgment
 29  3 or deferred judgment to the judicial district department of
 29  4 correctional services.
 29  5    Sec. 53.  Section 804.7, subsection 5, Code 2016, is amended
 29  6 to read as follows:
 29  7    5.  If the peace officer has reasonable grounds for believing
 29  8 that domestic abuse, as defined in section 236.2,  26 19 if section 708.6 or 708.8 applies.

 29  6 to read as follows:
 29  7    5.  If the peace officer has reasonable grounds for believing
 29  8 that domestic abuse, as defined in section 236.2,  26 23 throat or neck of the other person or by obstructing the nose
 26 24 or mouth of the other person.
 26 25    3.  Except as otherwise provided in subsection 2, on a second
 26 26 dating abuse assault, a person commits:
 26 27    a.  A serious misdemeanor, if the first offense was
 26 28 classified as a simple misdemeanor, and the second offense
 26 29 would otherwise be classified as a simple misdemeanor.
 26 30    b.  An aggravated misdemeanor, if the first offense was
 26 31 classified as a simple or aggravated misdemeanor, and the
 26 32 second offense would otherwise be classified as a serious
 26 33 misdemeanor, or the first offense was classified as a serious
 26 34 or aggravated misdemeanor, and the second offense would
 26 35 otherwise be classified as a simple or serious misdemeanor.
 27  1    4.  On a third or subsequent offense of dating abuse assault,
 27  2 a person commits a class "D" felony.
 27  3    5.  For a dating abuse assault committed by knowingly
 27  4 impeding the normal breathing or circulation of the blood of
 27  5 another by applying pressure to the throat or neck of the other
 27  6 person or by obstructing the nose or mouth of the other person,
 27  7 and causing bodily injury, the person commits a class "D"
 27  8 felony.
 27  9    6.  a.  A conviction for, deferred judgment for, or plea of
 27 10 guilty to, a violation of this section which occurred more than
 27 11 twelve years prior to the date of the violation charged shall
 27 12 not be considered in determining that the violation charged is
 27 13 a second or subsequent offense.
 27 14    b.  For the purpose of determining if a violation charged
 27 15 is a second or subsequent offense, deferred judgments issued
 27 16 pursuant to section 907.3 for violations of section 708.2 or
 27 17 this section, which were issued on dating abuse assaults,
 27 18 and convictions or the equivalent of deferred judgments for
 27 19 violations in any other states under statutes substantially
 27 20 corresponding to this section shall be counted as previous
 27 21 offenses. The courts shall judicially notice the statutes of
 27 22 other states which define offenses substantially equivalent
 27 23 to the offenses defined in this section and can therefore be
 27 24 considered corresponding statutes. Each previous violation on
 27 25 which conviction or deferral of judgment was entered prior to
 27 26 the date of the offense charged shall be considered and counted
 27 27 as a separate previous offense.
 27 28    c.  An offense shall be considered a prior offense regardless
 27 29 of whether it was committed upon the same victim.
 27 30    7.  a.  A person convicted of violating subsection 2 or 3
 27 31 shall serve a minimum term of two days of the sentence imposed
 27 32 by law, and shall not be eligible for suspension of the minimum
 27 33 sentence. The minimum term shall be served on consecutive
 27 34 days. The court shall not impose a fine in lieu of the minimum
 27 35 sentence, although a fine may be imposed in addition to the
 28  1 minimum sentence. This section does not prohibit the court
 28  2 from sentencing and the person from serving the maximum term of
 28  3 confinement or from paying the maximum fine permitted pursuant
 28  4 to chapter 902 or 903, and does not prohibit the court from
 28  5 entering a deferred judgment or sentence pursuant to section
 28  6 907.3, if the person has not previously received a deferred
 28  7 sentence or judgment for a violation of section 708.2 or this
 28  8 section which was issued on a dating abuse assault.
 28  9    b.  A person convicted of violating subsection 4 shall
 28 10 be sentenced as provided under section 902.9, subsection 1,
 28 11 paragraph "e", and shall be denied parole or work release until
 28 12 the person has served a minimum of one year of the person's
 28 13 sentence. Notwithstanding section 901.5, subsections 1, 3, and
 28 14 5, and section 907.3, the person cannot receive a suspended or
 28 15 deferred sentence or a deferred judgment; however, the person
 28 16 sentenced shall receive credit for any time the person was
 28 17 confined in a jail or detention facility following arrest.
 28 18    8.  If a person is convicted for, receives a deferred
 28 19 judgment for, or pleads guilty to a violation of this section,
 28 20 the court shall modify the no=contact order issued upon initial
 28 21 appearance in the manner provided in section 664A.5, regardless
 28 22 of whether the person is placed on probation.
 28 23    9.  The clerk of the district court shall provide notice
 28 24 and copies of a judgment entered under this section to the
 28 25 applicable law enforcement agencies and the twenty=four=hour
 28 26 dispatcher for the law enforcement agencies, in the manner
 28 27 provided for protective orders under section 236A.7. The
 28 28 clerk shall provide notice and copies of modifications of the
 28 29 judgment in the same manner.
 28 30    10.  In addition to the mandatory minimum term of confinement
 28 31 imposed by subsection 7, paragraph "a", the court shall order
 28 32 a person convicted under subsection 2 or 3 to participate
 28 33 in a batterers' treatment program as required under section
 28 34 708.2B.  In addition, as a condition of deferring judgment or
 28 35 sentence pursuant to section 907.3, the court shall order the
 29  1 person to participate in a batterers' treatment program. The
 29  2 clerk of the district court shall send a copy of the judgment
 29  3 or deferred judgment to the judicial district department of
 29  4 correctional services.
 29  5    Sec. 53.  Section 804.7, subsection 5, Code 2016, is amended
 29  6 to read as follows:
 29  7    5.  If the peace officer has reasonable grounds for believing
 29  8 that domestic abuse, as defined in section 236.2,  26 24 or mouth of the other person.
 26 25    3.  Except as otherwise provided in subsection 2, on a second

 26 29 would otherwise be classified as a simple misdemeanor.
 26 30    b.  An aggravated misdemeanor, if the first offense was
 26 31 classified as a simple or aggravated misdemeanor, and the
 26 32 second offense would otherwise be classified as a serious
 26 33 misdemeanor, or the first offense was classified as a serious
 26 34 or aggravated misdemeanor, and the second offense would
 26 35 otherwise be classified as a simple or serious misdemeanor.
 27  1    4.  On a third or subsequent offense of dating abuse assault,
 27  2 a person commits a class "D" felony.

 27  4 impeding the normal breathing or circulation of the blood of
 27  5 another by applying pressure to the throat or neck of the other
 27  6 person or by obstructing the nose or mouth of the other person,

 27 34 days. The court shall not impose a fine in lieu of the minimum

 28  1 minimum sentence. This section does not prohibit the court

 28 13 sentence. Notwithstanding section 901.5, subsections 1, 3, and
 28 14 5, and section 907.3, the person cannot receive a suspended or
 28 15 deferred sentence or a deferred judgment; however, the person
 28 16 sentenced shall receive credit for any time the person was
 28 17 confined in a jail or detention facility following arrest.
 28 18    8.  If a person is convicted for, receives a deferred
 28 19 judgment for, or pleads guilty to a violation of this section,
 28 20 the court shall modify the no=contact order issued upon initial
 28 21 appearance in the manner provided in section 664A.5, regardless
 28 22 of whether the person is placed on probation.
 28 23    9.  The clerk of the district court shall provide notice
 28 24 and copies of a judgment entered under this section to the
 28 25 applicable law enforcement agencies and the twenty=four=hour
 28 26 dispatcher for the law enforcement agencies, in the manner
 28 27 provided for protective orders under section 236A.7. The
 28 28 clerk shall provide notice and copies of modifications of the
 28 29 judgment in the same manner.
 28 30    10.  In addition to the mandatory minimum term of confinement
 28 31 imposed by subsection 7, paragraph "a", the court shall order
 28 32 a person convicted under subsection 2 or 3 to participate
 28 33 in a batterers' treatment program as required under section
 28 34 708.2B.  In addition, as a condition of deferring judgment or
 28 35 sentence pursuant to section 907.3, the court shall order the
 29  1 person to participate in a batterers' treatment program. The
 29  2 clerk of the district court shall send a copy of the judgment
 29  3 or deferred judgment to the judicial district department of
 29  4 correctional services.
