 28 31 imposed by subsection 7, paragraph "a", the court shall order
 28 32 a person convicted under subsection 2 or 3 to participate
 28 33 in a batterers' treatment program as required under section
 28 34 708.2B.  In addition, as a condition of deferring judgment or
 28 35 sentence pursuant to section 907.3, the court shall order the
 29  1 person to participate in a batterers' treatment program. The
 29  2 clerk of the district court shall send a copy of the judgment
 29  3 or deferred judgment to the judicial district department of
 29  4 correctional services.
 29  5    Sec. 53.  Section 804.7, subsection 5, Code 2016, is amended
 29  6 to read as follows:
 29  7    5.  If the peace officer has reasonable grounds for believing
 29  8 that domestic abuse, as defined in section 236.2,  26 29 would otherwise be classified as a simple misdemeanor.
 26 30    b.  An aggravated misdemeanor, if the first offense was
 26 31 classified as a simple or aggravated misdemeanor, and the
 26 32 second offense would otherwise be classified as a serious
 26 33 misdemeanor, or the first offense was classified as a serious
 26 34 or aggravated misdemeanor, and the second offense would
 26 35 otherwise be classified as a simple or serious misdemeanor.
 27  1    4.  On a third or subsequent offense of dating abuse assault,
 27  2 a person commits a class "D" felony.
 27  3    5.  For a dating abuse assault committed by knowingly
 27  4 impeding the normal breathing or circulation of the blood of
 27  5 another by applying pressure to the throat or neck of the other
 27  6 person or by obstructing the nose or mouth of the other person,
 27  7 and causing bodily injury, the person commits a class "D"
 27  8 felony.
 27  9    6.  a.  A conviction for, deferred judgment for, or plea of
 27 10 guilty to, a violation of this section which occurred more than
 27 11 twelve years prior to the date of the violation charged shall
 27 12 not be considered in determining that the violation charged is
 27 13 a second or subsequent offense.
 27 14    b.  For the purpose of determining if a violation charged
 27 15 is a second or subsequent offense, deferred judgments issued
 27 16 pursuant to section 907.3 for violations of section 708.2 or
 27 17 this section, which were issued on dating abuse assaults,
 27 18 and convictions or the equivalent of deferred judgments for
 27 19 violations in any other states under statutes substantially
 27 20 corresponding to this section shall be counted as previous
 27 21 offenses. The courts shall judicially notice the statutes of
 27 22 other states which define offenses substantially equivalent
 27 23 to the offenses defined in this section and can therefore be
 27 24 considered corresponding statutes. Each previous violation on
 27 25 which conviction or deferral of judgment was entered prior to
 27 26 the date of the offense charged shall be considered and counted
 27 27 as a separate previous offense.
 27 28    c.  An offense shall be considered a prior offense regardless
 27 29 of whether it was committed upon the same victim.
 27 30    7.  a.  A person convicted of violating subsection 2 or 3
 27 31 shall serve a minimum term of two days of the sentence imposed
 27 32 by law, and shall not be eligible for suspension of the minimum
 27 33 sentence. The minimum term shall be served on consecutive
 27 34 days. The court shall not impose a fine in lieu of the minimum
 27 35 sentence, although a fine may be imposed in addition to the
 28  1 minimum sentence. This section does not prohibit the court
 28  2 from sentencing and the person from serving the maximum term of
 28  3 confinement or from paying the maximum fine permitted pursuant
 28  4 to chapter 902 or 903, and does not prohibit the court from
 28  5 entering a deferred judgment or sentence pursuant to section
 28  6 907.3, if the person has not previously received a deferred
 28  7 sentence or judgment for a violation of section 708.2 or this
 28  8 section which was issued on a dating abuse assault.
 28  9    b.  A person convicted of violating subsection 4 shall
 28 10 be sentenced as provided under section 902.9, subsection 1,
 28 11 paragraph "e", and shall be denied parole or work release until
 28 12 the person has served a minimum of one year of the person's
 28 13 sentence. Notwithstanding section 901.5, subsections 1, 3, and
 28 14 5, and section 907.3, the person cannot receive a suspended or
 28 15 deferred sentence or a deferred judgment; however, the person
 28 16 sentenced shall receive credit for any time the person was
 28 17 confined in a jail or detention facility following arrest.
 28 18    8.  If a person is convicted for, receives a deferred
 28 19 judgment for, or pleads guilty to a violation of this section,
 28 20 the court shall modify the no=contact order issued upon initial
 28 21 appearance in the manner provided in section 664A.5, regardless
 28 22 of whether the person is placed on probation.
 28 23    9.  The clerk of the district court shall provide notice
 28 24 and copies of a judgment entered under this section to the
 28 25 applicable law enforcement agencies and the twenty=four=hour
 28 26 dispatcher for the law enforcement agencies, in the manner
 28 27 provided for protective orders under section 236A.7. The
 28 28 clerk shall provide notice and copies of modifications of the
 28 29 judgment in the same manner.
 28 30    10.  In addition to the mandatory minimum term of confinement
 28 31 imposed by subsection 7, paragraph "a", the court shall order
 28 32 a person convicted under subsection 2 or 3 to participate
 28 33 in a batterers' treatment program as required under section
 28 34 708.2B.  In addition, as a condition of deferring judgment or
 28 35 sentence pursuant to section 907.3, the court shall order the
 29  1 person to participate in a batterers' treatment program. The
 29  2 clerk of the district court shall send a copy of the judgment
 29  3 or deferred judgment to the judicial district department of
 29  4 correctional services.
 29  5    Sec. 53.  Section 804.7, subsection 5, Code 2016, is amended
 29  6 to read as follows:
 29  7    5.  If the peace officer has reasonable grounds for believing
 29  8 that domestic abuse, as defined in section 236.2,  26 30    b.  An aggravated misdemeanor, if the first offense was
 26 31 classified as a simple or aggravated misdemeanor, and the

 27  8 felony.
 27  9    6.  a.  A conviction for, deferred judgment for, or plea of
 27 10 guilty to, a violation of this section which occurred more than
 27 11 twelve years prior to the date of the violation charged shall
 27 12 not be considered in determining that the violation charged is
 27 13 a second or subsequent offense.
 27 14    b.  For the purpose of determining if a violation charged
 27 15 is a second or subsequent offense, deferred judgments issued
 27 16 pursuant to section 907.3 for violations of section 708.2 or
 27 17 this section, which were issued on dating abuse assaults,
 27 18 and convictions or the equivalent of deferred judgments for
 27 19 violations in any other states under statutes substantially
 27 20 corresponding to this section shall be counted as previous
 27 21 offenses. The courts shall judicially notice the statutes of
 27 22 other states which define offenses substantially equivalent
 27 23 to the offenses defined in this section and can therefore be
 27 24 considered corresponding statutes. Each previous violation on
 27 25 which conviction or deferral of judgment was entered prior to
 27 26 the date of the offense charged shall be considered and counted
 27 27 as a separate previous offense.
 27 28    c.  An offense shall be considered a prior offense regardless
 27 29 of whether it was committed upon the same victim.
 27 30    7.  a.  A person convicted of violating subsection 2 or 3
 27 31 shall serve a minimum term of two days of the sentence imposed
 27 32 by law, and shall not be eligible for suspension of the minimum
 27 33 sentence. The minimum term shall be served on consecutive
 27 34 days. The court shall not impose a fine in lieu of the minimum
 27 35 sentence, although a fine may be imposed in addition to the
 28  1 minimum sentence. This section does not prohibit the court
 28  2 from sentencing and the person from serving the maximum term of
 28  3 confinement or from paying the maximum fine permitted pursuant
 28  4 to chapter 902 or 903, and does not prohibit the court from
 28  5 entering a deferred judgment or sentence pursuant to section
 28  6 907.3, if the person has not previously received a deferred
 28  7 sentence or judgment for a violation of section 708.2 or this
 28  8 section which was issued on a dating abuse assault.
 28  9    b.  A person convicted of violating subsection 4 shall
 28 10 be sentenced as provided under section 902.9, subsection 1,
 28 11 paragraph "e", and shall be denied parole or work release until
 28 12 the person has served a minimum of one year of the person's
 28 13 sentence. Notwithstanding section 901.5, subsections 1, 3, and
 28 14 5, and section 907.3, the person cannot receive a suspended or
 28 15 deferred sentence or a deferred judgment; however, the person
 28 16 sentenced shall receive credit for any time the person was
 28 17 confined in a jail or detention facility following arrest.
 28 18    8.  If a person is convicted for, receives a deferred
 28 19 judgment for, or pleads guilty to a violation of this section,
 28 20 the court shall modify the no=contact order issued upon initial
 28 21 appearance in the manner provided in section 664A.5, regardless
 28 22 of whether the person is placed on probation.
 28 23    9.  The clerk of the district court shall provide notice
 28 24 and copies of a judgment entered under this section to the
 28 25 applicable law enforcement agencies and the twenty=four=hour
 28 26 dispatcher for the law enforcement agencies, in the manner
 28 27 provided for protective orders under section 236A.7. The
 28 28 clerk shall provide notice and copies of modifications of the
 28 29 judgment in the same manner.
 28 30    10.  In addition to the mandatory minimum term of confinement
 28 31 imposed by subsection 7, paragraph "a", the court shall order
 28 32 a person convicted under subsection 2 or 3 to participate
 28 33 in a batterers' treatment program as required under section
 28 34 708.2B.  In addition, as a condition of deferring judgment or
 28 35 sentence pursuant to section 907.3, the court shall order the
 29  1 person to participate in a batterers' treatment program. The
 29  2 clerk of the district court shall send a copy of the judgment
 29  3 or deferred judgment to the judicial district department of
 29  4 correctional services.
 29  5    Sec. 53.  Section 804.7, subsection 5, Code 2016, is amended
 29  6 to read as follows:
 29  7    5.  If the peace officer has reasonable grounds for believing
 29  8 that domestic abuse, as defined in section 236.2,  27  1    4.  On a third or subsequent offense of dating abuse assault,
 27  2 a person commits a class "D" felony.
 27  3    5.  For a dating abuse assault committed by knowingly
 27  4 impeding the normal breathing or circulation of the blood of
 27  5 another by applying pressure to the throat or neck of the other
 27  6 person or by obstructing the nose or mouth of the other person,
 27  7 and causing bodily injury, the person commits a class "D"
 27  8 felony.
 27  9    6.  a.  A conviction for, deferred judgment for, or plea of
 27 10 guilty to, a violation of this section which occurred more than
 27 11 twelve years prior to the date of the violation charged shall
 27 12 not be considered in determining that the violation charged is
 27 13 a second or subsequent offense.
 27 14    b.  For the purpose of determining if a violation charged
 27 15 is a second or subsequent offense, deferred judgments issued
 27 16 pursuant to section 907.3 for violations of section 708.2 or
 27 17 this section, which were issued on dating abuse assaults,
 27 18 and convictions or the equivalent of deferred judgments for
 27 19 violations in any other states under statutes substantially
 27 20 corresponding to this section shall be counted as previous
 27 21 offenses. The courts shall judicially notice the statutes of
 27 22 other states which define offenses substantially equivalent
 27 23 to the offenses defined in this section and can therefore be
 27 24 considered corresponding statutes. Each previous violation on
 27 25 which conviction or deferral of judgment was entered prior to
 27 26 the date of the offense charged shall be considered and counted
 27 27 as a separate previous offense.
 27 28    c.  An offense shall be considered a prior offense regardless
 27 29 of whether it was committed upon the same victim.
 27 30    7.  a.  A person convicted of violating subsection 2 or 3
 27 31 shall serve a minimum term of two days of the sentence imposed
 27 32 by law, and shall not be eligible for suspension of the minimum
 27 33 sentence. The minimum term shall be served on consecutive
 27 34 days. The court shall not impose a fine in lieu of the minimum
 27 35 sentence, although a fine may be imposed in addition to the
 28  1 minimum sentence. This section does not prohibit the court
 28  2 from sentencing and the person from serving the maximum term of
 28  3 confinement or from paying the maximum fine permitted pursuant
 28  4 to chapter 902 or 903, and does not prohibit the court from
 28  5 entering a deferred judgment or sentence pursuant to section
 28  6 907.3, if the person has not previously received a deferred
 28  7 sentence or judgment for a violation of section 708.2 or this
 28  8 section which was issued on a dating abuse assault.

 28 11 paragraph "e", and shall be denied parole or work release until

 28 13 sentence. Notwithstanding section 901.5, subsections 1, 3, and
 28 14 5, and section 907.3, the person cannot receive a suspended or
 28 15 deferred sentence or a deferred judgment; however, the person
 28 16 sentenced shall receive credit for any time the person was
 28 17 confined in a jail or detention facility following arrest.
 28 18    8.  If a person is convicted for, receives a deferred
 28 19 judgment for, or pleads guilty to a violation of this section,
 28 20 the court shall modify the no=contact order issued upon initial
 28 21 appearance in the manner provided in section 664A.5, regardless
 28 22 of whether the person is placed on probation.
 28 23    9.  The clerk of the district court shall provide notice
 28 24 and copies of a judgment entered under this section to the
 28 25 applicable law enforcement agencies and the twenty=four=hour
 28 26 dispatcher for the law enforcement agencies, in the manner
 28 27 provided for protective orders under section 236A.7. The
 28 28 clerk shall provide notice and copies of modifications of the
 28 29 judgment in the same manner.
 28 30    10.  In addition to the mandatory minimum term of confinement
 28 31 imposed by subsection 7, paragraph "a", the court shall order
 28 32 a person convicted under subsection 2 or 3 to participate
 28 33 in a batterers' treatment program as required under section
 28 34 708.2B.  In addition, as a condition of deferring judgment or
 28 35 sentence pursuant to section 907.3, the court shall order the
 29  1 person to participate in a batterers' treatment program. The
 29  2 clerk of the district court shall send a copy of the judgment
 29  3 or deferred judgment to the judicial district department of
 29  4 correctional services.
 29  5    Sec. 53.  Section 804.7, subsection 5, Code 2016, is amended

 29  1 person to participate in a batterers' treatment program. The
 29  2 clerk of the district court shall send a copy of the judgment
 29  3 or deferred judgment to the judicial district department of
 29  4 correctional services.
 29  5    Sec. 53.  Section 804.7, subsection 5, Code 2016, is amended
 29  6 to read as follows:
 29  7    5.  If the peace officer has reasonable grounds for believing
 29  8 that domestic abuse, as defined in section 236.2,  27  7 and causing bodily injury, the person commits a class "D"
 27  8 felony.
 27  9    6.  a.  A conviction for, deferred judgment for, or plea of
 27 10 guilty to, a violation of this section which occurred more than
 27 11 twelve years prior to the date of the violation charged shall
 27 12 not be considered in determining that the violation charged is
 27 13 a second or subsequent offense.
 27 14    b.  For the purpose of determining if a violation charged
 27 15 is a second or subsequent offense, deferred judgments issued
 27 16 pursuant to section 907.3 for violations of section 708.2 or
 27 17 this section, which were issued on dating abuse assaults,
 27 18 and convictions or the equivalent of deferred judgments for
 27 19 violations in any other states under statutes substantially
 27 20 corresponding to this section shall be counted as previous
 27 21 offenses. The courts shall judicially notice the statutes of
 27 22 other states which define offenses substantially equivalent
 27 23 to the offenses defined in this section and can therefore be
 27 24 considered corresponding statutes. Each previous violation on
 27 25 which conviction or deferral of judgment was entered prior to
 27 26 the date of the offense charged shall be considered and counted
 27 27 as a separate previous offense.
 27 28    c.  An offense shall be considered a prior offense regardless
 27 29 of whether it was committed upon the same victim.
 27 30    7.  a.  A person convicted of violating subsection 2 or 3
 27 31 shall serve a minimum term of two days of the sentence imposed
 27 32 by law, and shall not be eligible for suspension of the minimum
 27 33 sentence. The minimum term shall be served on consecutive
 27 34 days. The court shall not impose a fine in lieu of the minimum
 27 35 sentence, although a fine may be imposed in addition to the
 28  1 minimum sentence. This section does not prohibit the court
 28  2 from sentencing and the person from serving the maximum term of
 28  3 confinement or from paying the maximum fine permitted pursuant
 28  4 to chapter 902 or 903, and does not prohibit the court from
 28  5 entering a deferred judgment or sentence pursuant to section
 28  6 907.3, if the person has not previously received a deferred
 28  7 sentence or judgment for a violation of section 708.2 or this
 28  8 section which was issued on a dating abuse assault.
 28  9    b.  A person convicted of violating subsection 4 shall
 28 10 be sentenced as provided under section 902.9, subsection 1,
 28 11 paragraph "e", and shall be denied parole or work release until
 28 12 the person has served a minimum of one year of the person's
 28 13 sentence. Notwithstanding section 901.5, subsections 1, 3, and
 28 14 5, and section 907.3, the person cannot receive a suspended or
 28 15 deferred sentence or a deferred judgment; however, the person
 28 16 sentenced shall receive credit for any time the person was
 28 17 confined in a jail or detention facility following arrest.
 28 18    8.  If a person is convicted for, receives a deferred
 28 19 judgment for, or pleads guilty to a violation of this section,
 28 20 the court shall modify the no=contact order issued upon initial
 28 21 appearance in the manner provided in section 664A.5, regardless
 28 22 of whether the person is placed on probation.
 28 23    9.  The clerk of the district court shall provide notice
 28 24 and copies of a judgment entered under this section to the
 28 25 applicable law enforcement agencies and the twenty=four=hour
 28 26 dispatcher for the law enforcement agencies, in the manner
 28 27 provided for protective orders under section 236A.7. The
 28 28 clerk shall provide notice and copies of modifications of the
 28 29 judgment in the same manner.
 28 30    10.  In addition to the mandatory minimum term of confinement
 28 31 imposed by subsection 7, paragraph "a", the court shall order
 28 32 a person convicted under subsection 2 or 3 to participate
 28 33 in a batterers' treatment program as required under section
 28 34 708.2B.  In addition, as a condition of deferring judgment or
 28 35 sentence pursuant to section 907.3, the court shall order the
 29  1 person to participate in a batterers' treatment program. The
 29  2 clerk of the district court shall send a copy of the judgment
 29  3 or deferred judgment to the judicial district department of
 29  4 correctional services.
 29  5    Sec. 53.  Section 804.7, subsection 5, Code 2016, is amended
 29  6 to read as follows:

 28  6 907.3, if the person has not previously received a deferred
 28  7 sentence or judgment for a violation of section 708.2 or this
 28  8 section which was issued on a dating abuse assault.
 28  9    b.  A person convicted of violating subsection 4 shall
 28 10 be sentenced as provided under section 902.9, subsection 1,
 28 11 paragraph "e", and shall be denied parole or work release until
 28 12 the person has served a minimum of one year of the person's
 28 13 sentence. Notwithstanding section 901.5, subsections 1, 3, and
 28 14 5, and section 907.3, the person cannot receive a suspended or
 28 15 deferred sentence or a deferred judgment; however, the person
 28 16 sentenced shall receive credit for any time the person was
 28 17 confined in a jail or detention facility following arrest.
 28 18    8.  If a person is convicted for, receives a deferred
 28 19 judgment for, or pleads guilty to a violation of this section,
 28 20 the court shall modify the no=contact order issued upon initial
 28 21 appearance in the manner provided in section 664A.5, regardless
 28 22 of whether the person is placed on probation.
 28 23    9.  The clerk of the district court shall provide notice
 28 24 and copies of a judgment entered under this section to the
 28 25 applicable law enforcement agencies and the twenty=four=hour
 28 26 dispatcher for the law enforcement agencies, in the manner
 28 27 provided for protective orders under section 236A.7. The
 28 28 clerk shall provide notice and copies of modifications of the
 28 29 judgment in the same manner.
 28 30    10.  In addition to the mandatory minimum term of confinement
 28 31 imposed by subsection 7, paragraph "a", the court shall order
 28 32 a person convicted under subsection 2 or 3 to participate
 28 33 in a batterers' treatment program as required under section
 28 34 708.2B.  In addition, as a condition of deferring judgment or
 28 35 sentence pursuant to section 907.3, the court shall order the
 29  1 person to participate in a batterers' treatment program. The
 29  2 clerk of the district court shall send a copy of the judgment
 29  3 or deferred judgment to the judicial district department of
 29  4 correctional services.
 29  5    Sec. 53.  Section 804.7, subsection 5, Code 2016, is amended
 29  6 to read as follows:
 29  7    5.  If the peace officer has reasonable grounds for believing
 29  8 that domestic abuse, as defined in section 236.2,  27 15 is a second or subsequent offense, deferred judgments issued
 27 16 pursuant to section 907.3 for violations of section 708.2 or
 27 17 this section, which were issued on dating abuse assaults,
 27 18 and convictions or the equivalent of deferred judgments for
 27 19 violations in any other states under statutes substantially
 27 20 corresponding to this section shall be counted as previous
 27 21 offenses. The courts shall judicially notice the statutes of
 27 22 other states which define offenses substantially equivalent
 27 23 to the offenses defined in this section and can therefore be
 27 24 considered corresponding statutes. Each previous violation on
 27 25 which conviction or deferral of judgment was entered prior to
 27 26 the date of the offense charged shall be considered and counted
 27 27 as a separate previous offense.
 27 28    c.  An offense shall be considered a prior offense regardless
 27 29 of whether it was committed upon the same victim.
 27 30    7.  a.  A person convicted of violating subsection 2 or 3
 27 31 shall serve a minimum term of two days of the sentence imposed
 27 32 by law, and shall not be eligible for suspension of the minimum
 27 33 sentence. The minimum term shall be served on consecutive
 27 34 days. The court shall not impose a fine in lieu of the minimum
 27 35 sentence, although a fine may be imposed in addition to the
 28  1 minimum sentence. This section does not prohibit the court
 28  2 from sentencing and the person from serving the maximum term of
 28  3 confinement or from paying the maximum fine permitted pursuant
 28  4 to chapter 902 or 903, and does not prohibit the court from
 28  5 entering a deferred judgment or sentence pursuant to section
 28  6 907.3, if the person has not previously received a deferred
 28  7 sentence or judgment for a violation of section 708.2 or this
 28  8 section which was issued on a dating abuse assault.
 28  9    b.  A person convicted of violating subsection 4 shall
 28 10 be sentenced as provided under section 902.9, subsection 1,
 28 11 paragraph "e", and shall be denied parole or work release until
 28 12 the person has served a minimum of one year of the person's
 28 13 sentence. Notwithstanding section 901.5, subsections 1, 3, and
 28 14 5, and section 907.3, the person cannot receive a suspended or
 28 15 deferred sentence or a deferred judgment; however, the person
 28 16 sentenced shall receive credit for any time the person was
 28 17 confined in a jail or detention facility following arrest.
 28 18    8.  If a person is convicted for, receives a deferred
 28 19 judgment for, or pleads guilty to a violation of this section,
 28 20 the court shall modify the no=contact order issued upon initial
 28 21 appearance in the manner provided in section 664A.5, regardless
 28 22 of whether the person is placed on probation.
 28 23    9.  The clerk of the district court shall provide notice
 28 24 and copies of a judgment entered under this section to the
 28 25 applicable law enforcement agencies and the twenty=four=hour
 28 26 dispatcher for the law enforcement agencies, in the manner
 28 27 provided for protective orders under section 236A.7. The
 28 28 clerk shall provide notice and copies of modifications of the
 28 29 judgment in the same manner.
 28 30    10.  In addition to the mandatory minimum term of confinement
 28 31 imposed by subsection 7, paragraph "a", the court shall order
 28 32 a person convicted under subsection 2 or 3 to participate
 28 33 in a batterers' treatment program as required under section
 28 34 708.2B.  In addition, as a condition of deferring judgment or
 28 35 sentence pursuant to section 907.3, the court shall order the
 29  1 person to participate in a batterers' treatment program. The
 29  2 clerk of the district court shall send a copy of the judgment
 29  3 or deferred judgment to the judicial district department of
 29  4 correctional services.
 29  5    Sec. 53.  Section 804.7, subsection 5, Code 2016, is amended

 28 34 708.2B.  In addition, as a condition of deferring judgment or
 28 35 sentence pursuant to section 907.3, the court shall order the
 29  1 person to participate in a batterers' treatment program. The
 29  2 clerk of the district court shall send a copy of the judgment
 29  3 or deferred judgment to the judicial district department of
 29  4 correctional services.
 29  5    Sec. 53.  Section 804.7, subsection 5, Code 2016, is amended
 29  6 to read as follows:
 29  7    5.  If the peace officer has reasonable grounds for believing
 29  8 that domestic abuse, as defined in section 236.2,  27 23 to the offenses defined in this section and can therefore be
 27 24 considered corresponding statutes. Each previous violation on
 27 25 which conviction or deferral of judgment was entered prior to
 27 26 the date of the offense charged shall be considered and counted
 27 27 as a separate previous offense.
 27 28    c.  An offense shall be considered a prior offense regardless
 27 29 of whether it was committed upon the same victim.
 27 30    7.  a.  A person convicted of violating subsection 2 or 3
 27 31 shall serve a minimum term of two days of the sentence imposed
 27 32 by law, and shall not be eligible for suspension of the minimum
 27 33 sentence. The minimum term shall be served on consecutive
 27 34 days. The court shall not impose a fine in lieu of the minimum
 27 35 sentence, although a fine may be imposed in addition to the
 28  1 minimum sentence. This section does not prohibit the court
 28  2 from sentencing and the person from serving the maximum term of
 28  3 confinement or from paying the maximum fine permitted pursuant
 28  4 to chapter 902 or 903, and does not prohibit the court from
 28  5 entering a deferred judgment or sentence pursuant to section
 28  6 907.3, if the person has not previously received a deferred
 28  7 sentence or judgment for a violation of section 708.2 or this
 28  8 section which was issued on a dating abuse assault.
 28  9    b.  A person convicted of violating subsection 4 shall
 28 10 be sentenced as provided under section 902.9, subsection 1,
 28 11 paragraph "e", and shall be denied parole or work release until
 28 12 the person has served a minimum of one year of the person's
 28 13 sentence. Notwithstanding section 901.5, subsections 1, 3, and
 28 14 5, and section 907.3, the person cannot receive a suspended or
 28 15 deferred sentence or a deferred judgment; however, the person
 28 16 sentenced shall receive credit for any time the person was
 28 17 confined in a jail or detention facility following arrest.
 28 18    8.  If a person is convicted for, receives a deferred
 28 19 judgment for, or pleads guilty to a violation of this section,
 28 20 the court shall modify the no=contact order issued upon initial
 28 21 appearance in the manner provided in section 664A.5, regardless
 28 22 of whether the person is placed on probation.
 28 23    9.  The clerk of the district court shall provide notice
 28 24 and copies of a judgment entered under this section to the
 28 25 applicable law enforcement agencies and the twenty=four=hour
 28 26 dispatcher for the law enforcement agencies, in the manner
 28 27 provided for protective orders under section 236A.7. The
 28 28 clerk shall provide notice and copies of modifications of the
 28 29 judgment in the same manner.
 28 30    10.  In addition to the mandatory minimum term of confinement
 28 31 imposed by subsection 7, paragraph "a", the court shall order
 28 32 a person convicted under subsection 2 or 3 to participate
 28 33 in a batterers' treatment program as required under section
 28 34 708.2B.  In addition, as a condition of deferring judgment or
 28 35 sentence pursuant to section 907.3, the court shall order the
 29  1 person to participate in a batterers' treatment program. The
 29  2 clerk of the district court shall send a copy of the judgment
 29  3 or deferred judgment to the judicial district department of
 29  4 correctional services.

 28 22 of whether the person is placed on probation.
 28 23    9.  The clerk of the district court shall provide notice
 28 24 and copies of a judgment entered under this section to the
 28 25 applicable law enforcement agencies and the twenty=four=hour
 28 26 dispatcher for the law enforcement agencies, in the manner
 28 27 provided for protective orders under section 236A.7. The
 28 28 clerk shall provide notice and copies of modifications of the
 28 29 judgment in the same manner.
 28 30    10.  In addition to the mandatory minimum term of confinement
 28 31 imposed by subsection 7, paragraph "a", the court shall order
 28 32 a person convicted under subsection 2 or 3 to participate
 28 33 in a batterers' treatment program as required under section
 28 34 708.2B.  In addition, as a condition of deferring judgment or
 28 35 sentence pursuant to section 907.3, the court shall order the
 29  1 person to participate in a batterers' treatment program. The
 29  2 clerk of the district court shall send a copy of the judgment
 29  3 or deferred judgment to the judicial district department of
 29  4 correctional services.
 29  5    Sec. 53.  Section 804.7, subsection 5, Code 2016, is amended
 29  6 to read as follows:
 29  7    5.  If the peace officer has reasonable grounds for believing
 29  8 that domestic abuse, as defined in section 236.2,  27 33 sentence. The minimum term shall be served on consecutive
 27 34 days. The court shall not impose a fine in lieu of the minimum
 27 35 sentence, although a fine may be imposed in addition to the
 28  1 minimum sentence. This section does not prohibit the court
 28  2 from sentencing and the person from serving the maximum term of
 28  3 confinement or from paying the maximum fine permitted pursuant
 28  4 to chapter 902 or 903, and does not prohibit the court from
 28  5 entering a deferred judgment or sentence pursuant to section
 28  6 907.3, if the person has not previously received a deferred
 28  7 sentence or judgment for a violation of section 708.2 or this
 28  8 section which was issued on a dating abuse assault.
 28  9    b.  A person convicted of violating subsection 4 shall
 28 10 be sentenced as provided under section 902.9, subsection 1,
 28 11 paragraph "e", and shall be denied parole or work release until
 28 12 the person has served a minimum of one year of the person's
 28 13 sentence. Notwithstanding section 901.5, subsections 1, 3, and
 28 14 5, and section 907.3, the person cannot receive a suspended or
 28 15 deferred sentence or a deferred judgment; however, the person
 28 16 sentenced shall receive credit for any time the person was
 28 17 confined in a jail or detention facility following arrest.
 28 18    8.  If a person is convicted for, receives a deferred
 28 19 judgment for, or pleads guilty to a violation of this section,
 28 20 the court shall modify the no=contact order issued upon initial
 28 21 appearance in the manner provided in section 664A.5, regardless
 28 22 of whether the person is placed on probation.

 29  1 person to participate in a batterers' treatment program. The
 29  2 clerk of the district court shall send a copy of the judgment
 29  3 or deferred judgment to the judicial district department of
 29  4 correctional services.
 29  5    Sec. 53.  Section 804.7, subsection 5, Code 2016, is amended
 29  6 to read as follows:
 29  7    5.  If the peace officer has reasonable grounds for believing
 29  8 that domestic abuse, as defined in section 236.2,  28 10 be sentenced as provided under section 902.9, subsection 1,
 28 11 paragraph "e", and shall be denied parole or work release until
 28 12 the person has served a minimum of one year of the person's

 28 14 5, and section 907.3, the person cannot receive a suspended or
 28 15 deferred sentence or a deferred judgment; however, the person
 28 16 sentenced shall receive credit for any time the person was
 28 17 confined in a jail or detention facility following arrest.

 28 19 judgment for, or pleads guilty to a violation of this section,

 28 21 appearance in the manner provided in section 664A.5, regardless
 28 22 of whether the person is placed on probation.

 31 31 year shall not revert to the general fund of the state.
 31 32                           EXPLANATION
 31 33 The inclusion of this explanation does not constitute agreement with
 31 34 the explanation's substance by the members of the general assembly.
 31 35    This bill relates to civil protective orders and dating
 32  1 abuse, creates the criminal offense of dating abuse assault,
 32  2 and provides penalties.
 32  3    The bill creates new Code chapter 236A, the dating abuse
 32  4 Act, allowing a victim of dating abuse to seek relief from
 32  5 dating abuse by filing a petition in district court for a
 32  6 dating abuse civil protective order (emergency, temporary,
 32  7 and permanent) prior to the arrest of the defendant in such a
 32  8 situation affording the victim and the victim's family members,
 32  9 whose welfare may be affected by the dating abuse situation,
 32 10 the same civil protections as victims of domestic abuse under
 32 11 Code chapter 236.  The bill defines dating abuse as an assault
 32 12 between persons who are in a dating relationship or who have
 32 13 been in a dating relationship and who have had contact within
 32 14 the past year. The bill provides certain factors a court may
 32 15 consider in determining whether persons are or have been in a
 32 16 dating relationship.
 32 17    Under the bill, upon a finding by the court, by a
 32 18 preponderance of the evidence, that a defendant has engaged
 32 19 in dating abuse against the plaintiff, the court may order
 32 20 the defendant to cease the abuse, and order the defendant to
 32 21 stay away from the plaintiff's residence, school, or place
 32 22 of employment. In seeking a protective order, a victim has
 32 23 the right to seek help from the court with or without the
 32 24 assistance of an attorney and without the payment of court
 32 25 costs.
 32 26    The bill requires criminal or juvenile justice agencies to
 32 27 collect and maintain information on incidents involving dating
 32 28 abuse and to provide the information to the department of
 32 29 public safety. The bill provides certain provisions relating
 32 30 to the confidentiality of dating abuse victim records, the
 32 31 duties of a peace officer in dating abuse cases, and the duties
 32 32 of the department of justice relating to dating abuse training,
 32 33 services, and funding.
 32 34    The bill makes conforming changes to Code provisions,
 32 35 including those relating to the address confidentiality
 33  1 program, the issuance of and violations of civil protective
 33  2 orders, the duties of the departments of justice, public
 33  3 health, and corrections, Iowa law enforcement academy
 33  4 curriculum requirements, peace officer rights, delinquency
 33  5 detentions, dissolution proceedings, insurance practices,
 33  6 termination of parental rights proceedings, court and jail
 33  7 operating costs, peace officer arrests, and certain sentencing
 33  8 and victim rights and services provisions.
 33  9    The bill creates the criminal offense of dating abuse
 33 10 assault and provides penalties, including mandatory
 33 11 minimum fines and penalties, and fines, ranging from a
 33 12 simple misdemeanor to a class "D" felony, depending on the
 33 13 circumstances of the offense. The bill requires the court
 33 14 to order a defendant convicted of dating abuse assault to
 33 15 participate in a batterers' treatment program. A person
 33 16 arrested for a dating abuse assault is subject to a no=contact
 33 17 order.
       LSB 5256HH (9) 86
       rh/rj
 31 30 section 8.33, any balance in the fund on June 30 of any fiscal
 31 31 year shall not revert to the general fund of the state.
 31 32                           EXPLANATION
 31 33 The inclusion of this explanation does not constitute agreement with
 31 34 the explanation's substance by the members of the general assembly.
 31 35    This bill relates to civil protective orders and dating
 32  1 abuse, creates the criminal offense of dating abuse assault,
 32  2 and provides penalties.
 32  3    The bill creates new Code chapter 236A, the dating abuse
 32  4 Act, allowing a victim of dating abuse to seek relief from
 32  5 dating abuse by filing a petition in district court for a
 32  6 dating abuse civil protective order (emergency, temporary,
 32  7 and permanent) prior to the arrest of the defendant in such a
 32  8 situation affording the victim and the victim's family members,
 32  9 whose welfare may be affected by the dating abuse situation,
 32 10 the same civil protections as victims of domestic abuse under
 32 11 Code chapter 236.  The bill defines dating abuse as an assault
 32 12 between persons who are in a dating relationship or who have
 32 13 been in a dating relationship and who have had contact within
 32 14 the past year. The bill provides certain factors a court may
 32 15 consider in determining whether persons are or have been in a
 32 16 dating relationship.
 32 17    Under the bill, upon a finding by the court, by a
 32 18 preponderance of the evidence, that a defendant has engaged
 32 19 in dating abuse against the plaintiff, the court may order
 32 20 the defendant to cease the abuse, and order the defendant to
 32 21 stay away from the plaintiff's residence, school, or place
 32 22 of employment. In seeking a protective order, a victim has
 32 23 the right to seek help from the court with or without the
 32 24 assistance of an attorney and without the payment of court
 32 25 costs.
 32 26    The bill requires criminal or juvenile justice agencies to
 32 27 collect and maintain information on incidents involving dating
 32 28 abuse and to provide the information to the department of
 32 29 public safety. The bill provides certain provisions relating
 32 30 to the confidentiality of dating abuse victim records, the
 32 31 duties of a peace officer in dating abuse cases, and the duties
 32 32 of the department of justice relating to dating abuse training,
 32 33 services, and funding.
 32 34    The bill makes conforming changes to Code provisions,
 32 35 including those relating to the address confidentiality
 33  1 program, the issuance of and violations of civil protective
 33  2 orders, the duties of the departments of justice, public
 33  3 health, and corrections, Iowa law enforcement academy
 33  4 curriculum requirements, peace officer rights, delinquency
 33  5 detentions, dissolution proceedings, insurance practices,
 33  6 termination of parental rights proceedings, court and jail
 33  7 operating costs, peace officer arrests, and certain sentencing
 33  8 and victim rights and services provisions.
 33  9    The bill creates the criminal offense of dating abuse
 33 10 assault and provides penalties, including mandatory
 33 11 minimum fines and penalties, and fines, ranging from a
 33 12 simple misdemeanor to a class "D" felony, depending on the
 33 13 circumstances of the offense. The bill requires the court
 33 14 to order a defendant convicted of dating abuse assault to
 33 15 participate in a batterers' treatment program. A person
 33 16 arrested for a dating abuse assault is subject to a no=contact
 33 17 order.

 31 31 year shall not revert to the general fund of the state.
 31 32                           EXPLANATION
 31 33 The inclusion of this explanation does not constitute agreement with
 31 34 the explanation's substance by the members of the general assembly.
 31 35    This bill relates to civil protective orders and dating
 32  1 abuse, creates the criminal offense of dating abuse assault,
 32  2 and provides penalties.
 32  3    The bill creates new Code chapter 236A, the dating abuse
 32  4 Act, allowing a victim of dating abuse to seek relief from
 32  5 dating abuse by filing a petition in district court for a
 32  6 dating abuse civil protective order (emergency, temporary,
 32  7 and permanent) prior to the arrest of the defendant in such a
 32  8 situation affording the victim and the victim's family members,
 32  9 whose welfare may be affected by the dating abuse situation,
 32 10 the same civil protections as victims of domestic abuse under
 32 11 Code chapter 236.  The bill defines dating abuse as an assault
 32 12 between persons who are in a dating relationship or who have
 32 13 been in a dating relationship and who have had contact within
 32 14 the past year. The bill provides certain factors a court may
 32 15 consider in determining whether persons are or have been in a
 32 16 dating relationship.
 32 17    Under the bill, upon a finding by the court, by a
 32 18 preponderance of the evidence, that a defendant has engaged
 32 19 in dating abuse against the plaintiff, the court may order
 32 20 the defendant to cease the abuse, and order the defendant to
 32 21 stay away from the plaintiff's residence, school, or place
 32 22 of employment. In seeking a protective order, a victim has
 32 23 the right to seek help from the court with or without the
 32 24 assistance of an attorney and without the payment of court
 32 25 costs.
 32 26    The bill requires criminal or juvenile justice agencies to
 32 27 collect and maintain information on incidents involving dating
 32 28 abuse and to provide the information to the department of
 32 29 public safety. The bill provides certain provisions relating
 32 30 to the confidentiality of dating abuse victim records, the
 32 31 duties of a peace officer in dating abuse cases, and the duties
 32 32 of the department of justice relating to dating abuse training,
 32 33 services, and funding.
 32 34    The bill makes conforming changes to Code provisions,
 32 35 including those relating to the address confidentiality
 33  1 program, the issuance of and violations of civil protective
 33  2 orders, the duties of the departments of justice, public
 33  3 health, and corrections, Iowa law enforcement academy
 33  4 curriculum requirements, peace officer rights, delinquency
 33  5 detentions, dissolution proceedings, insurance practices,
 33  6 termination of parental rights proceedings, court and jail
 33  7 operating costs, peace officer arrests, and certain sentencing
 33  8 and victim rights and services provisions.
 33  9    The bill creates the criminal offense of dating abuse
 33 10 assault and provides penalties, including mandatory
 33 11 minimum fines and penalties, and fines, ranging from a
 33 12 simple misdemeanor to a class "D" felony, depending on the
 33 13 circumstances of the offense. The bill requires the court
 33 14 to order a defendant convicted of dating abuse assault to
 33 15 participate in a batterers' treatment program. A person
 33 16 arrested for a dating abuse assault is subject to a no=contact
 33 17 order.
       LSB 5256HH (9) 86
       rh/rj
 31 32                           EXPLANATION
 31 33 The inclusion of this explanation does not constitute agreement with
 31 34 the explanation's substance by the members of the general assembly.
 31 35    This bill relates to civil protective orders and dating
 32  1 abuse, creates the criminal offense of dating abuse assault,
 32  2 and provides penalties.
 32  3    The bill creates new Code chapter 236A, the dating abuse
 32  4 Act, allowing a victim of dating abuse to seek relief from
 32  5 dating abuse by filing a petition in district court for a
 32  6 dating abuse civil protective order (emergency, temporary,
 32  7 and permanent) prior to the arrest of the defendant in such a
 32  8 situation affording the victim and the victim's family members,
 32  9 whose welfare may be affected by the dating abuse situation,
 32 10 the same civil protections as victims of domestic abuse under
 32 11 Code chapter 236.  The bill defines dating abuse as an assault
 32 12 between persons who are in a dating relationship or who have
 32 13 been in a dating relationship and who have had contact within
 32 14 the past year. The bill provides certain factors a court may
 32 15 consider in determining whether persons are or have been in a
 32 16 dating relationship.
 32 17    Under the bill, upon a finding by the court, by a
 32 18 preponderance of the evidence, that a defendant has engaged
 32 19 in dating abuse against the plaintiff, the court may order
 32 20 the defendant to cease the abuse, and order the defendant to
 32 21 stay away from the plaintiff's residence, school, or place
 32 22 of employment. In seeking a protective order, a victim has
 32 23 the right to seek help from the court with or without the
 32 24 assistance of an attorney and without the payment of court
 32 25 costs.
 32 26    The bill requires criminal or juvenile justice agencies to
 32 27 collect and maintain information on incidents involving dating
 32 28 abuse and to provide the information to the department of
 32 29 public safety. The bill provides certain provisions relating
 32 30 to the confidentiality of dating abuse victim records, the
 32 31 duties of a peace officer in dating abuse cases, and the duties
 32 32 of the department of justice relating to dating abuse training,
 32 33 services, and funding.
 32 34    The bill makes conforming changes to Code provisions,
 32 35 including those relating to the address confidentiality
 33  1 program, the issuance of and violations of civil protective
 33  2 orders, the duties of the departments of justice, public
 33  3 health, and corrections, Iowa law enforcement academy
 33  4 curriculum requirements, peace officer rights, delinquency
 33  5 detentions, dissolution proceedings, insurance practices,
 33  6 termination of parental rights proceedings, court and jail
 33  7 operating costs, peace officer arrests, and certain sentencing
 33  8 and victim rights and services provisions.
 33  9    The bill creates the criminal offense of dating abuse
 33 10 assault and provides penalties, including mandatory
 33 11 minimum fines and penalties, and fines, ranging from a
 33 12 simple misdemeanor to a class "D" felony, depending on the
 33 13 circumstances of the offense. The bill requires the court
 33 14 to order a defendant convicted of dating abuse assault to
 33 15 participate in a batterers' treatment program. A person
 33 16 arrested for a dating abuse assault is subject to a no=contact
 33 17 order.

 32  2 and provides penalties.

 32  5 dating abuse by filing a petition in district court for a

 32  7 and permanent) prior to the arrest of the defendant in such a
 32  8 situation affording the victim and the victim's family members,
 32  9 whose welfare may be affected by the dating abuse situation,

 32 29 public safety. The bill provides certain provisions relating
 32 30 to the confidentiality of dating abuse victim records, the
 32 31 duties of a peace officer in dating abuse cases, and the duties
 32 32 of the department of justice relating to dating abuse training,
 32 33 services, and funding.
 32 34    The bill makes conforming changes to Code provisions,
 32 35 including those relating to the address confidentiality
 33  1 program, the issuance of and violations of civil protective
 33  2 orders, the duties of the departments of justice, public
 33  3 health, and corrections, Iowa law enforcement academy
 33  4 curriculum requirements, peace officer rights, delinquency
 33  5 detentions, dissolution proceedings, insurance practices,
 33  6 termination of parental rights proceedings, court and jail
 33  7 operating costs, peace officer arrests, and certain sentencing
 33  8 and victim rights and services provisions.

 33 10 assault and provides penalties, including mandatory
 33 11 minimum fines and penalties, and fines, ranging from a
 33 12 simple misdemeanor to a class "D" felony, depending on the
 33 13 circumstances of the offense. The bill requires the court
 33 14 to order a defendant convicted of dating abuse assault to
 33 15 participate in a batterers' treatment program. A person
 33 16 arrested for a dating abuse assault is subject to a no=contact
 33 17 order.

 31 35    This bill relates to civil protective orders and dating
 32  1 abuse, creates the criminal offense of dating abuse assault,
 32  2 and provides penalties.
 32  3    The bill creates new Code chapter 236A, the dating abuse
 32  4 Act, allowing a victim of dating abuse to seek relief from
 32  5 dating abuse by filing a petition in district court for a
 32  6 dating abuse civil protective order (emergency, temporary,
 32  7 and permanent) prior to the arrest of the defendant in such a
 32  8 situation affording the victim and the victim's family members,
 32  9 whose welfare may be affected by the dating abuse situation,
 32 10 the same civil protections as victims of domestic abuse under
 32 11 Code chapter 236.  The bill defines dating abuse as an assault
 32 12 between persons who are in a dating relationship or who have
 32 13 been in a dating relationship and who have had contact within
 32 14 the past year. The bill provides certain factors a court may
 32 15 consider in determining whether persons are or have been in a
 32 16 dating relationship.

 32 22 of employment. In seeking a protective order, a victim has

 32 25 costs.

 32 27 collect and maintain information on incidents involving dating
 32 28 abuse and to provide the information to the department of
 32 29 public safety. The bill provides certain provisions relating
 32 30 to the confidentiality of dating abuse victim records, the
 32 31 duties of a peace officer in dating abuse cases, and the duties
 32 32 of the department of justice relating to dating abuse training,
 32 33 services, and funding.
 32 34    The bill makes conforming changes to Code provisions,
 32 35 including those relating to the address confidentiality
 33  1 program, the issuance of and violations of civil protective
 33  2 orders, the duties of the departments of justice, public
 33  3 health, and corrections, Iowa law enforcement academy
 33  4 curriculum requirements, peace officer rights, delinquency
 33  5 detentions, dissolution proceedings, insurance practices,
 33  6 termination of parental rights proceedings, court and jail
 33  7 operating costs, peace officer arrests, and certain sentencing
 33  8 and victim rights and services provisions.

 33 10 assault and provides penalties, including mandatory
 33 11 minimum fines and penalties, and fines, ranging from a

 33 15 participate in a batterers' treatment program. A person
 33 16 arrested for a dating abuse assault is subject to a no=contact
 33 17 order.

 33  3 health, and corrections, Iowa law enforcement academy
 33  4 curriculum requirements, peace officer rights, delinquency
 33  5 detentions, dissolution proceedings, insurance practices,
 33  6 termination of parental rights proceedings, court and jail
 33  7 operating costs, peace officer arrests, and certain sentencing
 33  8 and victim rights and services provisions.
 33  9    The bill creates the criminal offense of dating abuse
 33 10 assault and provides penalties, including mandatory
 33 11 minimum fines and penalties, and fines, ranging from a
 33 12 simple misdemeanor to a class "D" felony, depending on the
 33 13 circumstances of the offense. The bill requires the court
 33 14 to order a defendant convicted of dating abuse assault to
 33 15 participate in a batterers' treatment program. A person
 33 16 arrested for a dating abuse assault is subject to a no=contact
 33 17 order.
       LSB 5256HH (9) 86
       rh/rj
 32  7 and permanent) prior to the arrest of the defendant in such a
 32  8 situation affording the victim and the victim's family members,
 32  9 whose welfare may be affected by the dating abuse situation,
 32 10 the same civil protections as victims of domestic abuse under
 32 11 Code chapter 236.  The bill defines dating abuse as an assault
 32 12 between persons who are in a dating relationship or who have
 32 13 been in a dating relationship and who have had contact within
 32 14 the past year. The bill provides certain factors a court may
 32 15 consider in determining whether persons are or have been in a
 32 16 dating relationship.
 32 17    Under the bill, upon a finding by the court, by a
 32 18 preponderance of the evidence, that a defendant has engaged
 32 19 in dating abuse against the plaintiff, the court may order
 32 20 the defendant to cease the abuse, and order the defendant to
 32 21 stay away from the plaintiff's residence, school, or place
 32 22 of employment. In seeking a protective order, a victim has
 32 23 the right to seek help from the court with or without the
 32 24 assistance of an attorney and without the payment of court
 32 25 costs.
 32 26    The bill requires criminal or juvenile justice agencies to
 32 27 collect and maintain information on incidents involving dating
 32 28 abuse and to provide the information to the department of
 32 29 public safety. The bill provides certain provisions relating
 32 30 to the confidentiality of dating abuse victim records, the
 32 31 duties of a peace officer in dating abuse cases, and the duties
 32 32 of the department of justice relating to dating abuse training,
 32 33 services, and funding.
 32 34    The bill makes conforming changes to Code provisions,
 32 35 including those relating to the address confidentiality
 33  1 program, the issuance of and violations of civil protective
 33  2 orders, the duties of the departments of justice, public
 33  3 health, and corrections, Iowa law enforcement academy
 33  4 curriculum requirements, peace officer rights, delinquency
 33  5 detentions, dissolution proceedings, insurance practices,
 33  6 termination of parental rights proceedings, court and jail
 33  7 operating costs, peace officer arrests, and certain sentencing
 33  8 and victim rights and services provisions.

 33 10 assault and provides penalties, including mandatory
 33 11 minimum fines and penalties, and fines, ranging from a
 33 12 simple misdemeanor to a class "D" felony, depending on the
 33 13 circumstances of the offense. The bill requires the court
 33 14 to order a defendant convicted of dating abuse assault to
 33 15 participate in a batterers' treatment program. A person
 33 16 arrested for a dating abuse assault is subject to a no=contact
 33 17 order.

 33 15 participate in a batterers' treatment program. A person
 33 16 arrested for a dating abuse assault is subject to a no=contact
 33 17 order.
       LSB 5256HH (9) 86
       rh/rj
 32 21 stay away from the plaintiff's residence, school, or place
 32 22 of employment. In seeking a protective order, a victim has
 32 23 the right to seek help from the court with or without the
 32 24 assistance of an attorney and without the payment of court
 32 25 costs.
 32 26    The bill requires criminal or juvenile justice agencies to
 32 27 collect and maintain information on incidents involving dating
 32 28 abuse and to provide the information to the department of
 32 29 public safety. The bill provides certain provisions relating
 32 30 to the confidentiality of dating abuse victim records, the
 32 31 duties of a peace officer in dating abuse cases, and the duties
 32 32 of the department of justice relating to dating abuse training,
 32 33 services, and funding.
 32 34    The bill makes conforming changes to Code provisions,
 32 35 including those relating to the address confidentiality
 33  1 program, the issuance of and violations of civil protective
 33  2 orders, the duties of the departments of justice, public
 33  3 health, and corrections, Iowa law enforcement academy
 33  4 curriculum requirements, peace officer rights, delinquency
 33  5 detentions, dissolution proceedings, insurance practices,
 33  6 termination of parental rights proceedings, court and jail
 33  7 operating costs, peace officer arrests, and certain sentencing
 33  8 and victim rights and services provisions.
 33  9    The bill creates the criminal offense of dating abuse
 33 10 assault and provides penalties, including mandatory
 33 11 minimum fines and penalties, and fines, ranging from a
 33 12 simple misdemeanor to a class "D" felony, depending on the
 33 13 circumstances of the offense. The bill requires the court
 33 14 to order a defendant convicted of dating abuse assault to
 33 15 participate in a batterers' treatment program. A person
 33 16 arrested for a dating abuse assault is subject to a no=contact
 33 17 order.
       LSB 5256HH (9) 86
